headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Republic Services Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Investor Conference Call. Republic Services is traded on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol RSG. [Operator Instructions] Please note this event is being recor
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Republic Services Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Investor Conference Call. Republic Services is traded on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol RSG. [Operator Instructions] Please note this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Brian Delghiaccio, Senior Vice President of Finance. Please go ahead.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. I would like to welcome everyone to Republic Services fourth quarter 2015 conference call. Don Slater, our CEO; and Chuck Serianni, our CFO, are joining me as we discuss our performance. I would like to take
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. I would like to welcome everyone to Republic Services fourth quarter 2015 conference call. Don Slater, our CEO; and Chuck Serianni, our CFO, are joining me as we discuss our performance. 
I would like to take a moment to remind everyone that some of the information we discuss on today's call contains forward-looking statements, which involve risks and uncertainties and may be materially different from actual results. Our SEC filings discuss factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from expectations. 
The material that we discuss today is time-sensitive. If in the future you listen to a rebroadcast or recording of this conference call, you should be sensitive to the date of the original call, which is February 11, 2016. 
Please note that this call is the property of Republic Services Inc. any redistribution, retransmission or rebroadcast of this call, in any form without the expressed written consent of Republic Services, is strictly prohibited. 
I want to point that our SEC filings, our earnings press release, which includes GAAP reconciliation tables, and a discussion of business activities, along with a recording of this call, are all available on the public's website at republicservices.com. 
And finally, I want to remind you that Republic's management team routinely participates investor conferences. When events are scheduled, the dates, times and presentations are posted on our website. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Don.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brian. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. We are pleased with our fourth quarter and full year results, which exceeded the upper end of our financial guidance. As a result of successfully executing our strategy, the Republic t
componenttext:
Thanks, Brian. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. We are pleased with our fourth quarter and full year results, which exceeded the upper end of our financial guidance. As a result of successfully executing our strategy, the Republic team delivered higher levels of pricing, reported positive volumes, grew earnings and free cash flow, improved return on invested capital and increased cash returns to shareholders. 
During 2015, we made significant progress on our multi-year strategic initiatives. These initiatives are designed to profitably grow our business, enhance the quality of our revenue, improve the customer experience and reduce costs. 
Regarding our market position. We invested $193 million in tuck-in acquisitions, nearly 2x our original goal. The transactions completed in 2015 represent annual revenue contribution of approximately $143 million at a post-synergy EBITDA multiple of 4.3x. And we acquired the U.S. assets of Tervita. These assets serve as a platform acquisition in the E&P waste sector with attractive long-term fundamentals and opportunities for future growth. 
Regarding our revenue enhancing initiatives, all of our markets are using our capture cloud-based pricing tool and our entire sales force has been trained on priority-based selling. Our sales program is designed to identify and attract customers that are willing to pay for our higher value service offerings. 
Additionally, we now have over 500 contracts with approximately $250 million in annual revenue that use the waste-related index for annual price adjustment. These waste indices are more closely aligned with our cost structure and consistently run higher than CPI. 
Most importantly, we are realizing the benefits of these revenue-enhancing initiatives. During 2015, we reported our highest level of average yield in over 5 years. Regarding our customers. We continue to see very encouraging customer engagement on our digital platform. For example, approximately 1.2 million customers have enrolled in MyResource, our customer portal and mobile app, which significantly enhances our customer interaction and connectivity. And we launched click to buy capabilities in approximately 50% of our residential subscription markets. Click-to-buy addresses the evolving needs of our customers' buying preferences and provides a lower-cost sales channel. 
Our customers see the difference in our products and services, which is reflected in our customer's satisfaction metrics. Our Net Promoter Score, which measures customers' willingness to recommend the company's products and services, improved for the third year in a row. 
And finally, regarding our fleet-based productivity and cost-savings initiatives, 16% of our total fleet now operates on natural gas. 72% of our residential fleet is currently automated and 78% of our total fleet has been certified under our 1 fleet maintenance program up from 60% a year ago. 
These initiatives required investment but the payback is compelling and our financial performance reflects the benefits we are seeing. Fourth quarter adjusted EPS was $0.50, which exceeded our expectations. Full year adjusted EPS was $2.06 and adjusted free cash flow was $813 million, both exceeded the upper end of our guidance. 
Core price in the fourth quarter was 3.4%, and average yield was 2.2%. Average yield exceeded 2% in every quarter during 2015. Fourth quarter volumes increased 90 basis points. This is the 11th consecutive quarter where we have grown price and volumes simultaneously. 
We returned $808 million to our shareholders through dividends and share repurchases during 2015. This includes approximately 10 million shares repurchased for $409 million. 
We finished the year with total shareholder return of 12.4%, which includes stock appreciation of 9.3% and dividends of 3.1%. Our TSR performance exceeded the S&P 500 average by over 8x. We made substantial progress in 2015 and are proud of our strong results and many accomplishments, but we have more to do. 
Last month, we entered the realignment of our organizational structure by combining 2 layers into one. This included the elimination of our 3 regions, the consolidation of 20 areas into 10 and streamlining select positions at our Phoenix headquarters. We are reinvesting back into our 10-area offices by creating additional operating and functional support roles, which puts resources closer to our business and our customers. 
Additionally, we are investing in our customer service capabilities and are in the process of consolidating over 100 customer service locations into 3 customer resource centers. The state of the facilities and technology will enable better levels of customer service across several touch points, including voice, e-mail, text, social and live chat. 
The savings from the realignment are funding the investments we are making at our customer-focused initiatives in 2016 and 2017. We expect these initiatives and realignment will contribute approximately $35 million of annual cost savings beginning in 2018. 
Our ability to make these organizational changes is a natural evolution and logical next step for our covenant. As a result of developing standardized processes with rigorous controls, we are further leveraging our scale to continually improve our service offerings. Additionally, we are able to maintain our high performance business culture with field management retaining full accountability and P&L responsibility. 
We call this approach the Republic Way, which we believe is the best way to create durable operational excellence and lasting value for all our stakeholders. 
Chuck will now discuss our financial results. Chuck?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don. Fourth quarter 2015 revenue was approximately $2.3 billion, an increase of $61 million over the prior year. This 2.7% increase in revenue includes internal growth of 90 basis points and acquisitions of 1.8%. The components of internal growt
componenttext:
Thanks, Don. Fourth quarter 2015 revenue was approximately $2.3 billion, an increase of $61 million over the prior year. This 2.7% increase in revenue includes internal growth of 90 basis points and acquisitions of 1.8%. 
The components of internal growth are as follows: first, average yield growth of 2.2%; average yield in the collections business was 2.7%, which includes 3.1% yield in a small container commercial business, 3.8% yield in the large container industrial business and 1.5% yield in the residential business. Average yield in the post-collection business was 70 basis points, which includes landfill MSW of 1.5%; core pricing, which measures price increases net of rollbacks were 3.4%; core price consisted of 4.4% in the open market and 1.7% in the restricted portion of our business. 
Second, our volumes increased 90 basis points year-over-year. The collection business increased 90 basis points, which includes positive contribution from the large container industrial business of 2.8% and the residential business of 40 basis points. The small container commercial business was flat with the prior year. 
Our small container commercial volume includes a 40-basis-point decline from non-regrettable losses of select National Accounts and were performed on behalf of brokers. The post-collection business, made up of third-party landfill and transfer station volumes, increased 1.8%. Landfill increased 2.1%, which includes positive MSW volumes of 5.5% and C&D of 8.2%, offset by decline in special waste volumes of 2.1%. 
The decline in special waste relates to same-store E&P volumes. Special waste volumes excluding E&P waste streams increased 1%. Next, fuel recovery fees decreased 170 basis points. The change relates to decline in the cost of fuel, which decreased approximately $33 million compared to the prior year. 
The average price per gallon of diesel decreased to $2.44 in the fourth quarter from $3.57 in the prior year, a decrease of 32%. The current average diesel price is $2.01 per gallon. We recover approximately 80% of our total fuel cost to our fuel recovery fee program. Additionally, 20% of our diesel gallons are hedged using financial hedges. 
Finally, commodity revenue decreased 50 basis points. The decrease in commodity sales primarily relates to a decrease in recycled commodity prices. Average commodity prices for all materials at our recycling facilities decreased 16% to an average price of $95 per ton in the fourth quarter from $113 per ton in the prior year. 
Excluding the glass and organics, average commodity prices decreased 14% to an average price of $108 per ton in the fourth quarter from $126 per ton in the prior year. 
We believe excluding glass and organics is a better way to report average commodity prices since they are low value wage streams and can skew the average price per ton. Our sensitivity to changing commodity prices has always excluded the impact from glass and organics. 
Again, I want to remind you that a $10 per ton move in recycling commodity prices results a $0.03 annual EPS impact. 
On our website, we posted the 3-year history of average commodity prices, including and excluding glass and organics. Fourth quarter total recycling volume of 648,000 tons represents an increase of approximately 14% from the prior year. Excluding acquisitions, volumes were up approximately 3%. Cost of goods sold for recycling commodities was relatively flat with the prior year. 
Now I will discuss changes in margin. Fourth quarter adjusted EBITDA margin was 27.2%, which was down 80 basis points from the prior year. The change included a 50-basis-point increase in SG&A expenses primarily due to higher levels of incentive compensation and investments in initiatives. And a 30-basis-point decline in EBITDA margin from lower recycled commodity prices. 
With respect to higher SG&A costs, the increased incentive compensation expense was due to financial outperformance during 2015. I also want to remind you that we expect the cost savings from the realignment to offset the investments in initiatives beginning in Q1 2016. 
On a full year basis, EBITDA margin was 28.1%, an improvement of 10 basis points over the prior year. Margin expansion in the solid waste business of 90 basis points, primarily due to lower fuel cost and pricing in excess of cost inflation, was partially offset by the impact of acquisitions of 40 basis points and lower recycling commodity prices of 40 basis points. 
When looking at individual cost line items as a percentage of revenue, there is an impact from the decrease in fuel recovery fees and a sale of recycled commodity revenue. 
For example, the 2.2% decline in these revenues resulted in increases in labor expense of 40 basis points and repairs and maintenance expense of 20 basis points. I want to remind you that we provide a detailed schedule of cost of operations and SG&A expenses in our 8-K filing. 
Fourth quarter 2015 interest expense was $93 million, which includes $12 million of noncash amortization. Our effective tax rate was 34.3% in the fourth quarter and 37.2% for the year. 
In 2016, we expect to return to our statutory effective tax rate of approximately 39.5%. The increase in our tax rate results in an $0.08 EPS headwind in 2016. 
Full year adjusted free cash flow was $813 million. This performance includes a cash tax benefit from the extension of bonus depreciation of approximately $65 million, and we expect bonus depreciation will provide a cash tax benefit of $30 million in 2016, resulting in a $35 million year-over-year cash tax headwind. 
Now, I will turn the call back to Don.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chuck. Before I open the call up for questions, I will provide our 2016 financial guidance. We expect adjusted earnings per share to be in a range of $2.13 to $2.17, which is consistent with the preliminary outlook we provided last October. This
componenttext:
Thanks, Chuck. Before I open the call up for questions, I will provide our 2016 financial guidance. 
We expect adjusted earnings per share to be in a range of $2.13 to $2.17, which is consistent with the preliminary outlook we provided last October. This continues to demonstrate the stability and predictability of our business. Our expected performance represent high single digit earnings growth after excluding the $0.08 headwind from the increase in our effective tax rate. 
We anticipate adjusted free cash flow to be in a range of $820 million to $840 million, which was upwardly revised from our preliminary outlook due to the extension of bonus depreciation. This performance represents mid- to high single-digit growth after excluding the change in cash taxes. 
We expect annual revenue growth of 2.5% to 3%, which includes average yield of approximately 2%. We believe this level of pricing is strong, given the 30-basis-point headwind from lower CPI-based recess. 
Volume growth in the range of 1/2 to 1%, we expect our volume trajectory to be relatively consistent with our full year 2015 performance. With the exception of residential due to noncontract losses, residential volumes are expected to be slightly negative. 
Contribution from acquisitions of 1%. This relates freely to tuck-in acquisitions and the rollover impact from 2015 transactions. And a decline in fuel recovery fees of 1% due to lower diesel prices. 
We anticipate an EBITDA margin of approximately 28.5%. This represents 40 basis points of margin expansion over our 2015 performance. 2016 net capital expenditures are expected to be $900 million or approximately 9.5% of revenue. This level of spending includes a $60 million benefit from cost effectively extending the useful life of our fleet as a result of our One Fleet maintenance program. This is in addition to the $40 million of capital we saved during 2015. 
We anticipate investing $100 million in tuck-in acquisitions, and we expect to return approximately $820 million of total cash to shareholders through $420 million of dividends and $400 million of share repurchases. 
I would like to thank the entire Republic team for their contributions that allowed us to meet our objectives and position us well for future growth. During 2016, we will continue to deliver on our promises to our key stakeholders, and remain focused on managing the business to create long-term value by executing our strategy of profitable growth through differentiation. 
At this time, operator, I would like to open the call to questions.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today is from Al Kaschalk from Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today is from Al Kaschalk from Wedbush Securities.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nice, a strong finish to the year. I want to focus, if I may, on the volume guidance, in particular, I think broader thoughts were that the sector could grow about 1% to 2% in '16. Maybe with some of these headwinds we're seeing in the broader economy tha
componenttext: Nice, a strong finish to the year. I want to focus, if I may, on the volume guidance, in particular, I think broader thoughts were that the sector could grow about 1% to 2% in '16. Maybe with some of these headwinds we're seeing in the broader economy that were a little too aggressive. But could you address the 50 basis points to 1% increase that you're looking for? And in particular, how large was the residential drop contracts that you lost?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually a couple of contracts. So this is normal in our business, Al and and the folks on the residential for a second. We've made a lot of noise out the fact that the residential business has been the weakest for some time. The residential business
componenttext: It's actually a couple of contracts. So this is normal in our business, Al and and the folks on the residential for a second. We've made a lot of noise out the fact that the residential business has been the weakest for some time. The residential business, some of those contracts, again, have the CPI resets, which don't really work for us over the long term. We've been very good public-private partners with our residential customers and we ultimately need to have contracts that work for both parties. And so we're taking a very strong approach to trying to get these contracts switched to a new index, which we talked about successfully. And there are some contracts, frankly, that just don't work for us. And so we're going to continue to be focused on return on investments. So the residential business can be a little bit weaker in 2016 as a result of that. And again, there is how many contracts do we have and the rest of the residential contracts?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thousands.
componenttext: Thousands.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thousands. So that's just the nature of the beast. That's going to be a little lumpy from year-to-year. The underlying economics, and we think are good, right. So we think about how we always talk about the fact that if it's population growth driving hous
componenttext: Thousands. So that's just the nature of the beast. That's going to be a little lumpy from year-to-year. The underlying economics, and we think are good, right. So we think about how we always talk about the fact that if it's population growth driving household formation that really is a critical metric in our business. If you look out and household formation is strong. It promises to continue to remain strong, it's steadily growing, that's good for us. The special waste business looks pretty solid, that's a good indicator of a good economy. And we've seen pretty consistent growth in even our MSW business over the last year. I mean, so I think we're in pretty good shape. We reported on the year 4-plus percent growth in MSW landfill, which that's nice to have across the business. So we'll continue to look for that. And then with the cash that's rolled to NPDES, we're being very selective about the kind of group we're getting. And as I said in my remarks, and the 11th straight quarter where we had both positive volume and pricing growth, we think that's the metric that we get both hand, and we continue to get both hands into the future and that's where we're focused. That's going to deliver both the margin and that's going to deliver the cash.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you sliced the volume overall, and I guess my question is a little bit more macro-driven, but historically, we've known that C&D has been a big beneficiary to the RSG/allied network. How would you look at that? And say, from either a manufacturing side
componenttext: If you sliced the volume overall, and I guess my question is a little bit more macro-driven, but historically, we've known that C&D has been a big beneficiary to the RSG/allied network. How would you look at that? And say, from either a manufacturing side, or, what concerns should we think about as shareholders be aware of, in terms of a slower economy, what that may impact? And in particular, what unmanaged actual verticals, how much are you exposed there?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, let's go back to all of that and remember, we tend to lag, right? So when these go up and down, we tend to lag a little bit. But when we talk about our large container industrial temp business, that's mostly construction. It's a large container tem
componenttext: First, let's go back to all of that and remember, we tend to lag, right? So when these go up and down, we tend to lag a little bit. But when we talk about our large container industrial temp business, that's mostly construction. It's a large container temp. When we talk about industrial large container [indiscernible], I mean, industrial is kind of a misnomer because that includes a lot of commercial retail business, a large, multifamily office, buildings, hospitals, anything that requires a large container. Only a portion of that large container business is truly industrial, right. And we've continued to see strong performance in that permanent business, both price and volumes. So we're not concerned about that segment of our business.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Corey Greendale of First Analysis.

componenttext: This is Ken Wang on for Corey. So just thinking about the incentive comp increase that you mentioned and looking at the labor cost as well, which would look like they were up about 6% year-on-year. Was the incentive comp increased something that also happened to affect on labor cost, just given on the increase?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, the incentive comp increase really occurred all on the SG&A line. And that was due to the financial outperformance that we had during 2015. And obviously, as we look at SG&A cost in 2016, we're not expecting that to repeat.
componenttext: No, the incentive comp increase really occurred all on the SG&A line. And that was due to the financial outperformance that we had during 2015. And obviously, as we look at SG&A cost in 2016, we're not expecting that to repeat.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Sure. And then in terms of the labor cost being up 6%, what was the driver there?
componenttext: Okay. Sure. And then in terms of the labor cost being up 6%, what was the driver there?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So keep in mind that 40 basis points of that is due to a reduction in the fuel recovery fee and commodity revenues, so it is really revenue base. And then the other 20% is really due to acquisitions.
componenttext: Sure. So keep in mind that 40 basis points of that is due to a reduction in the fuel recovery fee and commodity revenues, so it is really revenue base. And then the other 20% is really due to acquisitions.

componenttext: So Ken, when you're thinking about it -- you're just looking at the straight dollar increase? Is that right, the 6%, you're just taking a look at dollars to dollars, what you're looking at?

componenttext: Yes, that's right.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, remember, you have to  think about a normal inflation to business, and then when you think about on a full year basis, when you look at our volumes, it's been heavily weighted for the collection portion of our business, so there's a volume element to
componenttext: Yes, remember, you have to  think about a normal inflation to business, and then when you think about on a full year basis, when you look at our volumes, it's been heavily weighted for the collection portion of our business, so there's a volume element to it. And then you have to look at the total amount of acquisitions that we've completed during the year. So you add the 3 up together from the revenue perspective, because remember, within the revenue, you've got the reduction from fuel recovery in fee and commodities, that says nothing to your labor costs. So you have to look at the revenue change exclusive of those and basically, what you're seeing is a similar increase in labor expense, expressed as a percentage.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just this one quick follow-up. do you nay comments on any changes you've seen in competitor behavior, anything you're seeing either from large competitors or small competitors?
componenttext: And just this one quick follow-up. do you nay comments on any changes you've seen in competitor behavior, anything you're seeing either from large competitors or small competitors?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I would say, really no change over what we saw at the end of last year. Generally speaking, more broadly speaking, we feel pretty good about the sort of a rational behavior within the market generally. There's always a market or 2. There's always a lo
componenttext: No, I would say, really no change over what we saw at the end of last year. Generally speaking, more broadly speaking, we feel pretty good about the sort of a rational behavior within the market generally. There's always a market or 2. There's always a local competitor or two doing something, maybe making a bad decision or having bad debts and making investment here and there. But overall, we're not concerned about it.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Scott Levine of Imperial Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is from Scott Levine of Imperial Capital.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: So last year, I think you lowered off of your preliminary guidance for 2015 due to recycled commodity prices, dipping here, you're affirming the guidance. I was just kind of wondering, any appreciable changes in any of the assumptions or drivers beneath t
componenttext: So last year, I think you lowered off of your preliminary guidance for 2015 due to recycled commodity prices, dipping here, you're affirming the guidance. I was just kind of wondering, any appreciable changes in any of the assumptions or drivers beneath the surface of your business in 3Q to 4Q? Or is it really kind of status quo, no meaningful change in any particular area here?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, actually, there has been a change. I mean, we look at our outlook and look at our guidance right now. We've got about a $0.04 decrease due to commodity prices. So pretty significant decrease as we gave the outlook. But we've been able to offset that b
componenttext: No, actually, there has been a change. I mean, we look at our outlook and look at our guidance right now. We've got about a $0.04 decrease due to commodity prices. So pretty significant decrease as we gave the outlook. But we've been able to offset that by lower fuel cost and also through other improvements in the business and that's what allowed us to keep our guidance consistent with our outlook that we provided in October.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And as a follow-up, your capital allocations plan for '16, has you outspending free cash by a bit here, you've come off to pretty active years for M&A. Just looking for your confidence level maybe that you can continue to outspend free cas
componenttext: That's helpful. And as a follow-up, your capital allocations plan for '16, has you outspending free cash by a bit here, you've come off to pretty active years for M&A. Just looking for your confidence level maybe that you can continue to outspend free cash flow and grow the dividend and still remain comfortable with where your balance sheet leverage is.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're very comfortable with the balance sheet leverage. So right now, we're at 2.9x. When we look at our capital allocation, both in terms of dividends and share repurchases, it's right in line with the free cash flow. And I still have the capacity t
componenttext: Yes, we're very comfortable with the balance sheet leverage. So right now, we're at 2.9x. When we look at our capital allocation, both in terms of dividends and share repurchases, it's right in line with the free cash flow. And I still have the capacity that we need in order to pursue acquisitions. So we're very comfortable with the capital allocate -- allocation strategy and very comfortable with being able to continue to increase our dividends in the future.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: As it relates to the M&A, right, we can -- we've done a lot of pipeline of tuck-ins. We've got a pretty good handle, we think, on what is out there as it relates to tuck-in opportunities. But these larger opportunities that really drove the overspending,
componenttext: As it relates to the M&A, right, we can -- we've done a lot of pipeline of tuck-ins. We've got a pretty good handle, we think, on what is out there as it relates to tuck-in opportunities. But these larger opportunities that really drove the overspending, but we spend more in M&A last year, those are lumpy, right. Those come to the market once in a while. So we only see -- we don't have visibility to any of those today as we look at '16. And again, we're always focused on, first and foremost, to tuck-ins in our core markets, in our core business. So that gives us the better return and more risk, et cetera. But it's just that we always want to maintain the right strength in our capital structure so that if the right thing does come along for us, we've got the flexibility. So we're very focused on that.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Tyler Brown of Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question is from Tyler Brown of Raymond James.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, I want to talk about what I'm going to call your own idiosyncratic pricing stories. So at this point, captures rolled out, everybody is through PBS, my resources got increased penetration, and I assume all of that would drive better customer loyalty.
componenttext: Don, I want to talk about what I'm going to call your own idiosyncratic pricing stories. So at this point, captures rolled out, everybody is through PBS, my resources got increased penetration, and I assume all of that would drive better customer loyalty. So given all that, can you give us any metrics, maybe, even just directionally about maybe churn or spread between new and lost business? And going forward, would we expect to see the gap between core price and average yield narrow?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's back up. First of all, right, it's a pretty big denominator, right. So when you talk about -- we talk about taking defection from 7%, which it's been, and I remember defection's been an all-time double digit high in the past. We've got it down
componenttext:
Well, let's back up. First of all, right, it's a pretty big denominator, right. So when you talk about -- we talk about taking defection from 7%, which it's been, and I remember defection's been an all-time double digit high in the past. We've got it down to 9, 8, and now 7, it's been consistently 7 for some time, driving that down to 6 will be quite a feat, but we're focused on expanding customer loyalty. And half that affection is really competitive,  the other half is what we call structural business close, and this will et cetera. 
We are really focused in on the quality of the services we're delivering to our customers, through meeting our customer commitments, which is internal metric, and then also, Net Promoter Score, which as I said in my comments, we've improved our Net Promoter Score year-over-year for 3 years. So we're very, very active in trying to understand how our customers think about this. And then we brought forward not only better quality of service delivery but a better way of doing business with us through our digital platforms. So all those things are going to include the customer experience. And on top of that, the tool set you described around PBS, capture and also frankly, the improved CRM tool there today makes them one, or more efficient, more effective, but also helps them to get basically the price for a new selling to improve. And that's what's happening with what we're seeing with price, with yield and with churn. That churn, which is essentially the difference between business gain and business lost, right, a net difference, has continued there to narrow. That's been a big part of our pricing story, and we're going to continue to focus on that as we go through the year. It's a combination of all those things and working toward, again, sending loyalty, reducing churn, which ultimately means lower defection, and creating what we call internally, willingness to pay, right? And then PBS is directing our sales teams and customers that we believe are in the segments that are more likely to buy value and less likely to be only price customers. So everything we've been talking about over the past couple years getting rolled out has been working for the greater good. And it's reflected here and our best pricing ever in 2015 or in a long time anyway. And 11 straight quarters of both price and volume growth and I said that earlier question, we're going to be focused on the right growth, right, targeted, profitable unit growth. So we're seeing it and we're seeing margin expansion, we're seeing good cash flow as a result. So that's -- as you called it, my idiosyncratic price story.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to look at congressional funding for infrastructure that was asked last year, there's a fair amount of enthusiasm about new conversations and new projects and infrastructure. Does that impact -- I mean, do you think about that market as a potent
componenttext: I'm going to look at congressional funding for infrastructure that was asked last year, there's a fair amount of enthusiasm about new conversations and new projects and infrastructure. Does that impact -- I mean, do you think about that market as a potential opportunity for you? Does that impact your business over the next, let's say, 3 to 5 years?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: It does make a huge impact. If you think about that infrastructure build funding roads and bridges. We do work for our customers who build roads and bridges. But that doesn't generate the same kind of waste volume that comes out of doing track homes and m
componenttext: It does make a huge impact. If you think about that infrastructure build funding roads and bridges. We do work for our customers who build roads and bridges. But that doesn't generate the same kind of waste volume that comes out of doing track homes and multifamily homes and skyscrapers, right. The waste becomes a building site it's not something that's innovation and concrete. But things like putting up studs and drywall and carpeting and installation and ribbing, those kinds of things, generate waste from construction. So roads and bridges, we have some containers out along some of these building sites but unfortunately, for us, we don't get to pull them very often.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a few clarifying questions. On the organizational announcement or restructuring, what are the timing of it through 2016? Are there certain quarters where it's going to be more impactful?
componenttext: Just a few clarifying questions. On the organizational announcement or restructuring, what are the timing of it through 2016? Are there certain quarters where it's going to be more impactful?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me start -- I'll let Chuck talk about how the numbers roll in, but the reorganization is complete, right. So the reorganization is complete. The reorganization is functioning under the new model. And so basically, we have the absolute lower cost of or
componenttext: Let me start -- I'll let Chuck talk about how the numbers roll in, but the reorganization is complete, right. So the reorganization is complete. The reorganization is functioning under the new model. And so basically, we have the absolute lower cost of organization and functioning today, net of one time severances and relocations that some of the relocations have to occur over the next couple of months.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right. What we're saying is that the savings that we're going to receive from the realignment will really start in February, and that's about $20 million or so. Now that's going to be offset by additional investments in initiatives, primarily
componenttext: Yes, that's right. What we're saying is that the savings that we're going to receive from the realignment will really start in February, and that's about $20 million or so. Now that's going to be offset by additional investments in initiatives, primarily due to our customer resource centers. So that will be an offset within our P&L. We're also going to have about $35 million of restructuring charges, $25 million of that are associated with the realignment that Don just talked about. A lot of that should be front-end loaded, so more towards Q1, Q2. And then about $10 million of that associated with the customer resource centers. That's going to be more spread out through the year.

componenttext: If you -- I have this sense that the solid waste operating leverage is a little bit masked by some of the noise that happened throughout the year. If you were to strip away Tervita, how do you think about the solid waste profitability trends through the year and coming into 2016?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, let me start by going through some of the numbers. So if we just reconcile the EBITDA margin from '14 to '15, 2014 was at 28%, and we got about 90 basis points of margin expansion just from the solid waste from the base business. A lot of that du
componenttext: Michael, let me start by going through some of the numbers. So if we just reconcile the EBITDA margin from '14 to '15, 2014 was at 28%, and we got about 90 basis points of margin expansion just from the solid waste from the base business. A lot of that due to pricing above cost inflation and lower net fuel. That was offset during the year by the recycling business, which ended up being about 40 basis points and by acquisitions of about 40 basis points. So to your question, if you eliminate recycling and you eliminate the 40 basis points from acquisitions, it gives you a better idea of where we think the through margin potential is of the business, of the base business.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's very helpful. And then within the cash flow sort of discussion, you finished this year's cash flow from operations with a nice, healthy 18.4% of revs. That's a nice, healthy increase year-over-year. Usually, there's a nice deferred tax from t
componenttext: Okay. That's very helpful. And then within the cash flow sort of discussion, you finished this year's cash flow from operations with a nice, healthy 18.4% of revs. That's a nice, healthy increase year-over-year. Usually, there's a nice deferred tax from that starts as depreciation. But your guidance for next year, it looks like you're retaining a lot of that. It's still over 18%, so it's a lot like down a little bit at year-over-year, it's still over 18%, which is up on a long-term basis. So then you -- is that a sustainable permanent trend here now? You're at 18% or better CFS of ops going forward?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we would say that, that is, we believe that to be sustainable, Michael, going forward. We think about growing free cash flow at an annual basis, somewhere in the mid- to high single digits is something we feel comfortable with. And that's exactly wha
componenttext: Yes, we would say that, that is, we believe that to be sustainable, Michael, going forward. We think about growing free cash flow at an annual basis, somewhere in the mid- to high single digits is something we feel comfortable with. And that's exactly what we're doing this year if you exclude the impacts of bonus depreciation on both '15 and '16.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016

componenttext: That's right.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, the other way to think about this as well is that if you take a look at the 2015 guidance, right, for free cash flow of 820 million to 840 million, even to there's a $30 million benefit from the expense out of the extension of bonus depreciation,
componenttext: Michael, the other way to think about this as well is that if you take a look at the 2015 guidance, right, for free cash flow of 820 million to 840 million, even to there's a $30 million benefit from the expense out of the extension of bonus depreciation, if you look at the end year impact, right, so from all prior years together with what was just extended, it's still a net negative in '16 to the magnitude of about $20 million. So if you want to kind of think normalized, you would think that guidance and add $20 million, that's a normalized level of free cash flow had bonus depreciation never existed at all.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: So think about it, your first question, the underlying solid waste business expanded 90 basis points. Again, you had about some other noise. The cash flow point you made is right on and as you always say, you got to evolve the cash. If you think about wha
componenttext: So think about it, your first question, the underlying solid waste business expanded 90 basis points. Again, you had about some other noise. The cash flow point you made is right on and as you always say, you got to evolve the cash. If you think about what we've done in the business to shift the pricing to offset cost, we still got some good cost initiatives underway. Certainly, the reorganization and CRCs are part of that. And we have improvements still in our product set and in our customer service and so on to continue to drive willingness to pay. So we've shifted the gear here and now we're funding with some of those improvements funding the next wave of initiatives and so on. So we think we're going to continue to do that year-on-year and at some point in the future, there will be other ways of initiatives that we talk about still. And it's only going to do so much at one time, but we think we've turned the corner around.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just so I understood, Brian commented about what you were saying, I think, it was 65, if you normalized it, it would still be plus 20, and then that grows to 830 would be the midpoint less 30. So it's still showing growth. That's the point you were making
componenttext: Just so I understood, Brian commented about what you were saying, I think, it was 65, if you normalized it, it would still be plus 20, and then that grows to 830 would be the midpoint less 30. So it's still showing growth. That's the point you were making?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess what I was saying, Michael, is that if you just take the 2016 guide of 8 20 to 8 40, okay, if you take a look at the in year impact of bonus depreciation that we're going to see due to the reversal of prior years in '16 together with the in year b
componenttext: I guess what I was saying, Michael, is that if you just take the 2016 guide of 8 20 to 8 40, okay, if you take a look at the in year impact of bonus depreciation that we're going to see due to the reversal of prior years in '16 together with the in year benefit from the extension, when you take the net impact of that, that's still a net negative $20 million to free cash flow or $20 million in higher cash taxes than had bonus depreciation never existed at all. So the notion of kind of what normalized would be in a normal tax environment, it will be closer to 8 40 to 8 60, not 8 20 to 8 40 , that was what I was saying.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Andrew Buscaglia of Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is from Andrew Buscaglia of Crdit Suisse.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: On your fleet savings for rents, the 72% automated and 78% maintenance programs, do you expect those to be pretty much complete by the end of this year?
componenttext: On your fleet savings for rents, the 72% automated and 78% maintenance programs, do you expect those to be pretty much complete by the end of this year?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the -- we'll have the -- let's take it one at a time. The automation, right, is focused on the residential part of our business going from multiple individuals working on crude to single operator vehicles, right. So we moved that number up 2% or 3% a y
componenttext: So the -- we'll have the -- let's take it one at a time. The automation, right, is focused on the residential part of our business going from multiple individuals working on crude to single operator vehicles, right. So we moved that number up 2% or 3% a year. I think last year, we converted, what, 200 or 300 routes to single operators. So that's just been ticking up. That thing will probably max out somewhere at about 80%. I'd like to think it could be a little better, but some neighborhoods and some contracts just can't quite get there. So that's just going to continue to tick up year-on-year until we are fully automated. The one fleet initiative is going to be complete this year with all of our divisions being fully trained on One Fleet and then they will be certified, some of them will be still be in the certification process into the beginning of next year. But we're seeing the benefits of the most mature sites we talked about generally accrue in the business. So the longer these divisions are on [indiscernible] the program, the better they perform. And not to mention, right, obviously, the extension of the fleet that useful life of fleet, which is a very methodical [indiscernible] of our process and as I said in our comments, we're continually taking advantage of that and as a result of that, our CapEx this year is only about 95% [ph] of revenue.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right. So just to put a finer point on that, we had a -- we're expecting a $200 million capital savings associated with the One Fleet program. $40 million of that, we actually obtained in '15, and we're expecting another $60 million benefit in 2016
componenttext: That's right. So just to put a finer point on that, we had a -- we're expecting a $200 million capital savings associated with the One Fleet program. $40 million of that, we actually obtained in '15, and we're expecting another $60 million benefit in 2016.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay.
componenttext: Okay.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we originally said it would take 4 to 5 years to fully roll that out -- to take full advantage of extending the life.
componenttext: And we originally said it would take 4 to 5 years to fully roll that out -- to take full advantage of extending the life.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Okay. and then switching gears on the volume side. Can you just talk a little bit about your expectations, specifically on commercial volumes? I know they are flattish this quarter. What are you seeing, or what are you expecting in '16 for that
componenttext: All right. Okay. and then switching gears on the volume side. Can you just talk a little bit about your expectations, specifically on commercial volumes? I know they are flattish this quarter. What are you seeing, or what are you expecting in '16 for that segment?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we would say generally flat. We have a couple of things going on in there. We have, back to my comments earlier about more discipline, internal discipline on our end around price and volume, finding the right balance, really using the tools, the capt
componenttext: Yes, we would say generally flat. We have a couple of things going on in there. We have, back to my comments earlier about more discipline, internal discipline on our end around price and volume, finding the right balance, really using the tools, the capture tools, et cetera. We have talked about in previous quarters of the fact that we partnered with some nonprofitable National Accounts business. And we're going to continue to be very certain in our actions around that. And we've also walked away from some broker relationships. Those are third parties who don't own trucks, they don't own containers, they don't own landfills, they have no risk. They bring no value to the customer. And we have had some relationships there that we had to part ways with. And we're going to continue to be very selective with our partners. And that will impact our commercial small container growth in '16 and in '17, frankly. But we will continue to be flat, at least for '16 and ultimately, as the product continued to grow and everything else, we'll get our first year of growth and that's the thing we always say is, 2 in 40 markets [ph] 42 states, we're the #1 or #2 market positions, about 93% of those has growth is there, we get our fair share of growth and we want to focus that share on, again, customers who are in the right segments who value our quality and are willing to pay.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Fair enough.
componenttext: All right. Fair enough.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Michael Feniger from Banc of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is from Michael Feniger from Banc of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're guiding to EBITDA margins up 40 basis points. Can you just walk us through some puts and takes on what's helped you really expand that margin in a very tough CPI backdrop?
componenttext: You're guiding to EBITDA margins up 40 basis points. Can you just walk us through some puts and takes on what's helped you really expand that margin in a very tough CPI backdrop?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me put a little bit of color. First of all, on fourth quarter margins. And the EBITDA margin for Q4 2015 was 27.2%. Now included in that, you'll see that we had higher SG&A cost. Incentive comp was about 50 basis points higher. We had some legal
componenttext: Sure. Let me put a little bit of color. First of all, on fourth quarter margins. And the EBITDA margin for Q4 2015 was 27.2%. Now included in that, you'll see that we had higher SG&A cost. Incentive comp was about 50 basis points higher. We had some legal settlements of about 20 basis points. And we had some initiative investments of about 30 basis points. Now the initiative investments in 2016 are going to be offset by the cost savings from the realignment that I have talked about. And we're not expecting the initiative comp or the incentive comp and the legal settlements to reoccur. So just from that alone, you're ending up with 100 basis points more in margin for the quarter. And we're looking at SG&A in 2016 closer to 10.5% and once again, that has to -- it's a little bit higher than the 10% that we've called out just because of some of the cost that we're occurring, associated with initiatives. But after 2018 and getting the full benefit associated with both the realignment and the customer resource centers, we're expecting SG&A to be back to around 10%. So looking longer term, really we're going to be able to start leveraging our SG&A and that's going to be a primary driver of our margins going forward.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Mike, just to kind of look at if you look at the full year of year-over-year, what Chuck just described on the SG&A expenses, that's probably 30 basis points of the 40 basis points of margin expansion from '15 to '16 just on SG&A. And then the rest is
componenttext: And Mike, just to kind of look at if you look at the full year of year-over-year, what Chuck just described on the SG&A expenses, that's probably 30 basis points of the 40 basis points of margin expansion from '15 to '16 just on SG&A. And then the rest is basically just due to a better business performance.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then with free cash flow coming in ahead in '15 and the very healthy cash flow from operations, is there any thought about maybe taking up that tuck-in acquisition target of $100 million higher?
componenttext: Okay. And then with free cash flow coming in ahead in '15 and the very healthy cash flow from operations, is there any thought about maybe taking up that tuck-in acquisition target of $100 million higher?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we've got a target of $100 million, as I said, and we've got a pipeline. Each of our area Presidents and our general managers have responsibility to contribute to that pipeline with ideas around companies that might be interested in selling. Here's wha
componenttext: So we've got a target of $100 million, as I said, and we've got a pipeline. Each of our area Presidents and our general managers have responsibility to contribute to that pipeline with ideas around companies that might be interested in selling. Here's what I always say, right. In order to have a good deal, one of the main components of every good deal is having a willing seller, right. And I give you a willing seller, you need any good synergy, real synergy, you like to get real assets and real property and real goodwill of customers. We don't buy startups. We don't buy serial sellers. We like good, quality companies with recurring revenue and good assets. And so there's a limit to what is out there and there's a limit, frankly, to owners who are willing to sell, and they have got to be at a point in their lives frankly where they are. So we are going to be as optimistic as we can be. We think the tuck-in really looks like $100 million. If something comes along and it's not in our sites today, the only thing to know is, as the quarters tick off, we always have the capability to do more and that's one of the reasons that we maintain our capital structure the way that we do. And again, we're very focused on trying to grow the core, and we know the value of tucking more business into already a very strong management team and a really good, strong asset base. So if it's there, we'll take a look at it.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Adam Baumgarten of Macquarie.
componenttext: Our next question is from Adam Baumgarten of Macquarie.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on the post-collection yield. I mean, it's pretty stable quarter-over-quarter despite a pretty nice tick up in the MSW yield. Can you kind of walk me through the puts and takes there?
componenttext: Just a quick question on the post-collection yield. I mean, it's pretty stable quarter-over-quarter despite a pretty nice tick up in the MSW yield. Can you kind of walk me through the puts and takes there?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me back up again just to give you a sense too and then I'll let Chuck walk you through the numbers. But remember that post-collection, right, includes right transfer and landfill. And remember that a good portion of our landfill business today, MSW st
componenttext: Let me back up again just to give you a sense too and then I'll let Chuck walk you through the numbers. But remember that post-collection, right, includes right transfer and landfill. And remember that a good portion of our landfill business today, MSW still comes through as municipal waste from municipal customers, right. And a lot of that business -- so these are cities we have their own trash fleets, their own trucks collecting their own trash from rate payers, but they don't have their own landfills. And so unfortunately for us, some of those contracts are still in with their CPI escalators. So as we're thinking about moving to new indices, that is one of the areas that we'll focus on over time. In the other part of the business, so the open market part of the landfill business, we do much better. But it's heavily weighted still toward that municipal [indiscernible].

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a restricted piece of the business, the yield there is closer to 1.5%. And then to Don's point, the unerestricted price is probably closer to 3% or 4%.
componenttext: So a restricted piece of the business, the yield there is closer to 1.5%. And then to Don's point, the unerestricted price is probably closer to 3% or 4%.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just one quick one. Should we expect any material impact on key margins from the extra selling day?
componenttext: And then just one quick one. Should we expect any material impact on key margins from the extra selling day?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we think that there's going to be a downward pressure on margins of higher cost, I should say, in Q1 because of the extra selling day. That's true, about 30 to 40 basis points.
componenttext: Yes, we think that there's going to be a downward pressure on margins of higher cost, I should say, in Q1 because of the extra selling day. That's true, about 30 to 40 basis points.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the other thing, again, just to kind of keep in mind when you take a look at the first quarter, is last year, we got the benefit from the lag in the fuel recovery fee. And that was about a $0.02 EPS benefit. We contributed about 60 basis points to mar
componenttext: And the other thing, again, just to kind of keep in mind when you take a look at the first quarter, is last year, we got the benefit from the lag in the fuel recovery fee. And that was about a $0.02 EPS benefit. We contributed about 60 basis points to margin in the first quarter of '15. So when you look at the combination of the two, just kind of something to keep in mind as you're looking at your model for next year or for this year.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016

componenttext: At this time, there appear to be no further questions. Mr. Slater, I will turn the call back over to you for closing remarks.
