componenttext: So I just want to dig into the margin a little bit further. Your EBITDA margins are down 110 basis points, and if you add back the extra day, which is 50 basis points, it sounds like 40 or so basis points from health care problems, call it about a 20 basis point headwind. I'm just curious, if you were to normalized some of those other elevated expenses, whether it's leachate or disposal cost, where do you think that EBITDA margin would have shaken out, then?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's think about it this way, Joe. If you look at the EBITDA margin that we reported, 27.8%, add back to your point 40 basis points for the health expense. And then keep in mind that during Q1, you had your seasonally highest SG&A, so we're at 10.7 versu
componenttext: Let's think about it this way, Joe. If you look at the EBITDA margin that we reported, 27.8%, add back to your point 40 basis points for the health expense. And then keep in mind that during Q1, you had your seasonally highest SG&A, so we're at 10.7 versus our guidance of about 10.5 for the year. That's another 20 basis points. So a total of 60 basis points. Add that back to the 27.8% and you get 28.4%, which is right in line with our guidance for the year.

How out of whack do you think the revenues are relative to your processing cost? I'm just trying to understand what the overall benefit could be as this gets absorbed into the system.

componenttext: $70 a ton.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, right. So, and that's what we were enjoying, whatever it was 7 or 8 years ago, right. So we realigned the organizations, as we said, and we really focus on getting better profitability cost structure. And on the processing side, those folks are doing
componenttext: Yes, right. So, and that's what we were enjoying, whatever it was 7 or 8 years ago, right. So we realigned the organizations, as we said, and we really focus on getting better profitability cost structure. And on the processing side, those folks are doing a great job of that. We need to migrate that over to the collection side now and into some of the hauling contracts. It's going to take a little while. We probably have some routes out there that aren't dense enough that may never have enough participation or density to make sense. So we're going to be addressing that in the open market certainly and maybe even some of the contractual stuff. We've got to make more headway with our municipal partners. And as I said in my comments, we've got some examples, where we're negotiating glass surcharges. We're taking glass out. We're taking the rebate structure, the fee-based, et cetera. So we're getting better at it, but we're very, very early innings. I think, we're much further along in moving the municipal contracts to the new index. We've got more momentum there. We're breathing some fire now into the recycling collection business to move those contracts. I don't know how long this is going to take, Joe. It's going to depend a little bit on how -- what the market dynamic is. But we're not going to be caught with getting drunk again on high commodity prices, right? We've got to fix the business for good, get to the right sharing with our customer base. As I always say and as I said in my comments, sustainability doesn't words about profitability. That's what we're focused on, and we're not going to do business that has a diminishing return. So...

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will come from Michael Hoffman of Stifel.
componenttext: The next question will come from Michael Hoffman of Stifel.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So back to the CPI. At 1 point over the last couple of years, you had described the sort of pool of addressable revenues at about $2 billion. What do you think of the practical number that can be converted on a percentage basis? And where I'm going with t
componenttext: So back to the CPI. At 1 point over the last couple of years, you had described the sort of pool of addressable revenues at about $2 billion. What do you think of the practical number that can be converted on a percentage basis? And where I'm going with that is it would be a good thing if you got some number and then inflation comes back to 2%, and when the 2 blend together, you're net ahead of the game.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So again, with everybody listening, hopefully a lot of my teammates at Republic, right, we absolutely positively can't be entering into contracts with escalators that don't keep pace with our net inflation, inflation net of productivity. We got to
componenttext: Right. So again, with everybody listening, hopefully a lot of my teammates at Republic, right, we absolutely positively can't be entering into contracts with escalators that don't keep pace with our net inflation, inflation net of productivity. We got to be equal or better, right? And as I said many times, right, for decades, as long as I've been around, that CPI was great, it was fair, we need to get fairness again. And so, my viewpoint is all contracts have to be converted to a metric or an escalator that's fair and reasonable. So we're tackling this space. We said we got $2.5 billion of the business. About $800 million of that $2.5 billion is the smaller contracts. That's where we went to work first. Now we've got $325 million that's converted. Now we're working for bigger contracts. And we're right now, as we speak, talking to customers and very large customers about this very thing. And I think, at some point, we'll have made some of those conversions successful and the market will continue to move. So if you take a look at our pricing, this quarter, a 2% yield. We've been north of 2 now for a few quarters. What keeps holding us back down is residential. So we're very, very close to hitting this overarching metric for us of getting back to a day where yield surpasses inflation on a regular and consistent basis.  We're right on the cost of that. And so we're going to keep pushing the new metric. I don't have an exact day, date in mind where we can get there. I know we're making progress, Michael, and we're -- if you can tell the determination in my voice that we're kind of at the place where we're not taking no for an answer because we just can't be in a situation where we have these large contracts with a lot of exposure and declining returns. It's just not feasible or it's not practical.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, fair enough. Switching gears to margin trend. If I took your 50 basis points for adjustment to your gross margin, so instead of doing 38 6, you did 39 1 for the first quarter. Given how good the volume was and when possibly some of that got pul
componenttext: All right, fair enough. Switching gears to margin trend. And really, what you want to look at is smoothing first half and comparing that to the first half of '15?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: No, I don't think so, Michael. I think -- I don't know if we necessarily need to smooth this. Part of the noise that I think we might be seeing in the first quarter has to do with the workday. And we need to keep in mind that reverses, that in Q4, so there's going to be a little bit of pickup there when that happens. But I would say that right now, we feel pretty comfortable with our adjusted EBITDA margin guidance that we gave, the 28.5% for the year.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I wasn't disputing that. I was really just trying to figure out, given how strong volumes were in the first quarter, the operating leverage that comes from that. In all likelihood, those volumes remained good, but not as good as 1Q because of the po
componenttext: Okay. I wasn't disputing that. I was really just trying to figure out, given how strong volumes were in the first quarter, the operating leverage that comes from that. In all likelihood, those volumes remained good, but not as good as 1Q because of the positives circumstances, and therefore, you might see a slight shift in margin 1Q to the next. It's not a bad thing if you smooth the 2 accused together, you've got the objective you were trying to achieve anyway, but you've pulled some of that benefit into 1Q. So you're... go ahead.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was going to say, MICHAEL, this is Brian, remember the largest percentage of our volume growth was in the roll off business, which was up about 13%. And as you know, that comes along with the variable cost, so I know you were talking about leverage, but
componenttext: I was going to say, MICHAEL, this is Brian, remember the largest percentage of our volume growth was in the roll off business, which was up about 13%. And as you know, that comes along with the variable cost, so I know you were talking about leverage, but that's where we saw the concentration of volume. But the other thing is that we know that while it was a mild winter, in parts of the country, it was wet, right? So we did see extra operating cost. We saw higher disposal expense where we've got predominantly third-party disposal markets, and we saw some additional leachate expenses again where it was wet. So from a weather perspective, it's not that we feel that we've got a whole lot of contribution to the bottom line from the mild winter. So after revenues fall off a little bit in the second quarter because maybe they were pulled forward, we would also expect some of the cost to taper off as well.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough.
componenttext: Okay, fair enough.

componenttext: Yes To us, sometimes, the answer is timing and mix, Michael, right? [indiscernible] but you're right, I mean, I think the quarter was very strong. So we've got a little bit of noise with a few items and we've got a little bit of, as Chuck described with the residential volume, we got a couple of blips on the horizon there with contracts we'll walk away from. We talked in the comments about some volume, non-regrettable volumes loss with National Accounts and brokers. So there's some other noise in the system, but we're really confident in the guidance and in the margin, and more importantly, in the action we're taking and the way that the team is executing so.

We've got a slow start her eon the year, but we think we'll exit the year having very wisely spent the $100 million and invested it in some really good tuck-in assets.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. Last question from me, if I may. You mentioned higher leachate cost. One of your competitors also talked about it today on their call. Are there any sizable investments that you expect related to the Fisher?
componenttext: That's helpful. Last question from me, if I may. You mentioned higher leachate cost. One of your competitors also talked about it today on their call. Are there any sizable investments that you expect related to the Fisher?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, not really. For us, when we look at leachate, it's been somewhat unique to the individual landfill. I mean, it really is about the geology of the individual landfill and also the weather that exists, whether it's a dry climate or a wet climate. Obviou
componenttext: No, not really. For us, when we look at leachate, it's been somewhat unique to the individual landfill. I mean, it really is about the geology of the individual landfill and also the weather that exists, whether it's a dry climate or a wet climate. Obviously in the southwest, we don't have a lot of leachate. We don't have a lot of rain. We have eerie climates and the water evaporates. We've got some landfills that have integrated water flows that we've got to deal with, so that's a little bit of a different issue. So it's really site-specific. The leachate cost that we saw in Q1 was really more about a wet, a seasonally wet and unusually, seasonally wet quarter. Having said that, landfills are more expensive to own and operate every day and every year and we're constantly evaluating our cost structure and constantly looking for ways to effectively pass along price increases into the market that makes sense to capture the cost inflation. We've got to manage the things responsibly and be good environmental stewards and we'll continue to do that. But for us, leachate is really more of a site-specific issue, but that's all I can tell you it as we look at the quarter. There's nothing else for us to be going on broadly with our leachate story.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from Michael Feniger of Bank of America.
componenttext: And the next question will come from Michael Feniger of Bank of America.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Did you guys see any changes through the quarter in April when you're speaking about special event volume, C&D? Anything that makes you -- any cause for concern, that momentum you felt on the volume side would slow going into the second quarter?

componenttext: Well, no. I think, specifically to construction volume is strong, one, because of the unusual weather. But Q2 is where we tend to see the seasonal pickups and we certainly expect to see that. Event business and the special waste business was strong in Q1. There's no concern that we have there overall. I mean, we're still only at 1.1 million new home starts. Single-family home starts are actually up, right, on a year-over-year basis. So that bodes well for us. We tend to lag that. So as long as that continues, I think, that's what drives more and more growth in our markets.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the total macro basis, we're feeling really, really good.

componenttext: And a lot of the residential business that you guys were discussing, should we be thinking that as a positive for the mix? Would that be positive to margin?

componenttext: Yes. Well, ultimately, look, residential, it's our weakest line of business in our collection system, right? And you think about the state of affairs there that we've had the sustainable CPI environment for how many years?

componenttext: Six, 7 years.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Six, 7 years. It's averaged over that time 1.6%, right? Our cost don't average 1.6% and you could just do some math and figure out what kind of margin erosion we've had there in that space. That's why we're so adamant about changing the indices for someth
componenttext: Six, 7 years. It's averaged over that time 1.6%, right? Our cost don't average 1.6% and you could just do some math and figure out what kind of margin erosion we've had there in that space. That's why we're so adamant about changing the indices for something that's a fair and reasonable. So we get to a do a negotiation with a residential customer, who can't seem to understand that degree of fairness. We can't enter into extending contracts that continue to decline and go below our reasonable rate of return. So ultimately, we have to grow the ROI in the business. And so your point is over time, that's a good thing. We either have to shed business that doesn't equal the right return or we have to get a pricing scenario that is reasonable for both parties, so. And that's the story. It's the same story with National Accounts and some of the broker business, right?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: And the next question will come from Al Kaschalk of Wedbush Securities.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, I joined late, so -- but I wanted to focus on really, I guess, 2 areas: One, you talked a little bit about the leachate and maybe you can just take a step back and help us appreciate, is this more focused or more of a concern to companies that have
componenttext: Sorry, I joined late, so -- but I wanted to focus on really, I guess, 2 areas: One, you talked a little bit about the leachate and maybe you can just take a step back and help us appreciate, is this more focused or more of a concern to companies that have higher number of closed landfills than, say, maybe where storms or other things C&D occur and, therefore, water C&D increase? Can you just talk a little bit about that? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that in my comments earlier, leachate is really 2 things. I mean, we talked about it  being site-specific. It's really about geology and whether, right? You have a large -- if you have a large landfills with a big open space that's not cover
componenttext: Well, I think that in my comments earlier, leachate is really 2 things. I mean, we talked about it  being site-specific. It's really about geology and whether, right? You have a large -- if you have a large landfills with a big open space that's not covered, right, then you get a lot of rainfall. All that rainfall goes into your landfill and becomes leachate, okay? if you are in an air [indiscernible] where you don't have leachate or you don't have rainfall, you don't have that problem, right? So it's very site-specific. And again, as we have a lot of rainfall in certain parts of the country and certain parts of the year, we have snow normally. Snow tends to fall and sit on top of the landfill and then evaporate before it melts. Rainfall tends to get inside your landfill, right? So I'm not a weatherman, but that's kind of how it works, Al. So we have a number of closed landfills certainly. Some of those are so close that they're in earth, right, and there's virtually no leachate coming out of them, right? So once you complete the capital landfill and you see that completely closed state, there's no more rainwater getting into the landfill, right? So it's just about the timing, I guess, when it comes to that point. So for us, we don't have, from our perspective, as I said in an earlier question, a broad-based concern about leachate today. We have some specific sites that saw more leachate in the quarter because rainfall, and we're dealing with that through normal operating expense.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And just to put a final point on that, with the areas, the landfills that we saw that had an increase in leachate, they were active landfills in areas that had very, very heavy rains during the quarter.
componenttext: Yes. And just to put a final point on that, with the areas, the landfills that we saw that had an increase in leachate, they were active landfills in areas that had very, very heavy rains during the quarter.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So I guess, from the novice point being from my side, the item we want to focus on or center our questions on are those landfills that are closed, where you're not able to potentially charge someone for those extra costs you incur, versus an active
componenttext: Right. So I guess, from the novice point being from my side, the item we want to focus on or center our questions on are those landfills that are closed, where you're not able to potentially charge someone for those extra costs you incur, versus an active one, you theoretically have the ability to pass through some costs. Whether you get that, that's a whole different story. Is that fair?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm not sure I totally understand your question. I can't tell you off the top of my head the exact percentage of our leachate that comes from closed landfills and open landfills. But the majority of our leachate comes from open operating landfills. A
componenttext: Yes, I'm not sure I totally understand your question. I can't tell you off the top of my head the exact percentage of our leachate that comes from closed landfills and open landfills. But the majority of our leachate comes from open operating landfills. As I said, the longer the landfill is capped and closed, the less leachate is present in the landfill.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And keep in mind also, when we cap our landfills, there's a synthetic line that's put on top of it that prevents the leachate from going into the landfill.
componenttext: And keep in mind also, when we cap our landfills, there's a synthetic line that's put on top of it that prevents the leachate from going into the landfill.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So again, our leachate expense was normal across the company with the exception of those sites that saw a much higher level of rainfall than normal or potentially a landfill that was in the midst of construction and had a rainfall event while part of the
componenttext: So again, our leachate expense was normal across the company with the exception of those sites that saw a much higher level of rainfall than normal or potentially a landfill that was in the midst of construction and had a rainfall event while part of the landfill was opened where normally, it wouldn't be. But other than that, our leachate expense across the company net of those landfills is just inflating at what would be a normal inflation rate. And so we generally, to your pricing question, we generally deal with leachate expense and the cost of leachate expense through our environmental recovery fee with our landfill customers, right? And so over time, we raised our environmental recovery fee to deal with certain issues like leachate expense, and we've done that very effectively over recent years. And customers seem to understand that, so that's been our mechanism to deal with it.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And then my follow-up would be if you could give us some type of -- I won't say a macro for an economist, et cetera, but generally, I think at the peak, you had C&D volumes on landfill, I thought, were 17%, 18% of your revenue. You commented
componenttext: Okay, got it. And then my follow-up would be if you could give us some type of -- I won't say a macro for an economist, et cetera, but generally, I think at the peak, you had C&D volumes on landfill, I thought, were 17%, 18% of your revenue. You commented where housing starts are, et cetera, and you've always had a better leverage to or higher leverage, my understanding, than your competitors to sort of that your nonresidential construction activity. So, a, could you maybe just frame around in terms of percentage of revenue? And sort of how much more tailwind do we have on these positive volumes that we saw?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let's -- we don't really give a lot of data on non-res versus resi construction because that's [indiscernible] because again, it's less than important, and we're not economist either. Our total C&D for the company is about 8%, and at its peak, it wa
componenttext: Well, let's -- we don't really give a lot of data on non-res versus resi construction because that's [indiscernible] because again, it's less than important, and we're not economist either. Our total C&D for the company is about 8%, and at its peak, it was 12%, okay? At its peak. So if you think about -- I always think about it this way, right? Again, back to housing starts, we said for many moons now, our business grows with population growth that drives household formation, that drives business formation. And while that household formation does create some construction degree, what we really like to see is it creates the ongoing recurring revenue part of our business, which is the small-container, large-container pickups and pools that are ongoing. That's the part of our business that's kind of our bread and butter. And we know that the construction is going to ebb and flow a little bit with the economy. Having said that, housing starts are 1.1 million. The 50-year [ph] average, if you take the peak out, it's 1.5 million. Most of the people I talked to in the housing, business are pretty bullish on housing continuing to improve. I mentioned that single-family housing is our homes arch up like 20% so -- and we know we lag sort of 1 year-plus when that's happening. So when you think about housing being strong, we feel like that's going to keep our construction business strong, not only in '16, but well into '17, through '17 frankly. So that's kind of how we look at it. And how long this is going to take to get 1.1 million to 1.5 million, I'm not sure. But we know that we get our fair share of growth is, as proven here by Q1. Again, strong temp volume, 13% in that space. So we'll continue to do with that. So we feel overall pretty positive about the macro.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the Republic Services First Quarter 2016 Investor Conference Call. Republic Services is traded on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol RSG. [Operator Instructions] Please note this event is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Brian DelGhiaccio, Vice President of Finance. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. I would like to welcome everyone to Republic Services First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Don Slager, our CEO; and Chuck Serianni, our CFO, are joining me as we discuss our performance. I would like to take a
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. I would like to welcome everyone to Republic Services First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Don Slager, our CEO; and Chuck Serianni, our CFO, are joining me as we discuss our performance. I would like to take a moment to remind everyone that some of the information we discuss on today's call contains forward-looking statements, which involve risks and uncertainties and may be materially different from actual results. Our SEC filings discuss factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from expectations. The material that we discuss today is time sensitive. If, in the future, you listen to a rebroadcast or recording of this conference call, you should be sensitive to the date of the original call, which is April 28, 2016. Please note that this call is the property of Republic Services, Inc. Any redistribution, retransmission or rebroadcast of this call in any form without the expressed written consent of Republic Services is strictly prohibited.
I want to point out that our SEC filings, our earnings press release, which includes GAAP reconciliation tables, and a discussion of business activities, along with a recording of this call, are all available on Republic's website at republicservices.com. 
And finally, I want to remind you that Republic's management team routinely participates in investor conferences. When events are scheduled, the dates, times and presentations are posted on our website. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Don.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brian. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. We are pleased with our first quarter results, which were in line with our expectations and keep us well positioned to achieve our full year financial guidance. We continue to realize
componenttext:
Thanks, Brian. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. We are pleased with our first quarter results, which were in line with our expectations and keep us well positioned to achieve our full year financial guidance. We continue to realize the benefits of executing our strategy of profitable growth through differentiation, which allows us to attract and retain higher-value customers, build the best team, increase profitability and create long-term value. 
During the first quarter, we reported adjusted EPS of $0.48 and adjusted free cash flow of $160 million. Both were in line with our expectations. Core price was 3.4% and average yield was 2%. This was the fifth consecutive quarter with average yield of 2% or more. Average yield was strongest in our small-container commercial and large-container industrial businesses, where a majority of the business is in the open markets. In these open markets, we have greater flexibility and can realize more pricing power from our enhanced product offering and improved service delivery, and by leveraging our priority-based selling program and our Capture pricing tool.
First quarter volumes increased 2.5%. This included 50 basis points of contribution from 1 additional workday. Volume growth was concentrated to the event-driven waste streams, including construction and demolition and our collection and disposal business and landfill special waste. While a portion of this volume growth can be attributed to favorable weather conditions during the quarter, we saw broad-based volume growth across most of our markets. Additionally, landfill MSW volumes grew 4.7%. This was the fifth straight quarter where MSW volume growth exceeded 3%.
First quarter EBITDA margin was 27.8%. It should be noted that the additional workday resulted in a 50 basis point margin headwind, which will not repeat in future quarters. We returned $191 million to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases. This included 1.9 million shares repurchased for approximately $87 million.
Regarding our revenue-enhancing and customer-facing initiatives, first, we now have approximately $325 million in annual revenue that uses a waste-related index for the annual price adjustment. These waste indices are more closely aligned with our cost structure and have consistently ran higher than CPI. Second, approximately 1.4 million customers are enrolled in My Resource, our customer portal and mobile app, which significantly enhances our customer interaction and connectivity. Finally, we opened our first Customer Resource Center in Charlotte, North Carolina. The center further enhances our customers' experience through more professionally trained customer service team, improved technology and additional communication channels. We expect to open the other 2 Customer Resource Centers later this year.
Regarding our fleet-based productivity and cost-saving initiatives, 16% of our total fleet now operates on natural gas. 73% of our resi fleet is now currently automated and 81% of our total fleet has been certified under our One Fleet maintenance program, up from 64% a year ago. We are expediting the time line to get our entire fleet through the program by June of this year and fully certified by mid-2017.
During the quarter, we completed the realignment of our organizational structure. This included the elimination of our regional teams, consolidation or reduction of our areas by 50% and streamlining select positions at our Phoenix headquarters. We reinvested a portion of the cost savings back into the remaining area offices by creating additional operating and functional support roles, which puts resources closer to our business and our customers. We were able to make these changes as a result of developing standardized processes with rigorous controls and further leveraging our scale. At the same time, we maintained our high performance business culture with field management retaining full accountability and P&L responsibility. The savings from the realignment are funding the investments we are making in our customer-focused initiatives in 2016 and 2017. We expect these initiatives and the realignment will contribute approximately $35 million of annual cost savings beginning in 2018.
Before turning the call over to Chuck, I would like to provide an update on our recycling business. As many of you know, recycled commodity values have always been somewhat volatile. However, the industry has never experienced such a sustained downturn in commodity pricing. We continue to evolve our recycling strategy to adapt to this new normal.
We are focusing on 3 key areas to evolve our business model. First, as part of our realignment, we centralized management oversight and accountability for recycling processing operations. The new organizational structure ensures clear ownership for the recycling processing market vertical and provides additional expertise and support through our recycling collection operations. 
Second, we are transitioning to a fee-based recycling processing model. This model ensures that we can cover our processing cost and earn an acceptable return on our processing investments. Under this model, we are including provisions incentivize communities to bring us high-quality materials. This includes the right to conduct waste stream audits and assess contamination fees and glass surcharges.
And finally, we are optimizing our recycling collection business. Many municipal customers still believe there is significant value in the waste stream and are not aware of the cost to recover the material. Currently, our municipal sales team is focusing on educating municipal staff and elected officials on the all-in cost of recycling in these low commodity markets. Although we are still in the early innings, we are making progress. We transitioned our largest municipal processing agreement to a fee-based structure, negotiated a rebate reduction with a large customer on the East Coast and added a glass surcharge with a large customer in Texas. Our customers have told us they value recycling and are willing to pay for these services. Our collective actions to improve the performance of our recycling business is intended to create a model for Republic and our recycling customers that ensures profitability and, therefore, supports its long-term sustainability.
Chuck will now discuss our financial results.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don. First quarter 2016 revenue was approximately $2.2 billion, an increase of $79 million or 3.6% over the prior year. This 3.6% increase in revenue includes internal growth of 2.4% and acquisitions of 1.2%. The components of internal growth are
componenttext:
Thanks, Don. First quarter 2016 revenue was approximately $2.2 billion, an increase of $79 million or 3.6% over the prior year. This 3.6% increase in revenue includes internal growth of 2.4% and acquisitions of 1.2%. The components of internal growth are as follows: first, total average yield growth of 2%, average yield in the collection business was 2.4%, which includes 3.6% yield in the small-container commercial business, 2.3% yield in the large-container industrial business and 1% yield in the residential business. Average yield in the post-collection business was 1%, which includes landfill MSW of 1.5%. A majority of our third party landfill MSW business is with municipal customers that have contracts that contain pricing restrictions. Total core price, which measures price increases less rollbacks, was 3.4%. Core price consisted of 4.5% in the open market and 1.7% in the restructured portion of our business. 
Second, our total volumes increased 2.5% year-over-year. This includes 50 basis points of contribution from 1 additional workday. The following discussion of volume by line of business excludes the impact of the additional workday. 
The collection business increased 1.4%, which includes increases from the large container business of 5.1% and the small container business of 20 basis points. As expected, the residential business declined 10 basis points.
With our large container business, temporary C&D volumes were up 13% and recurring volumes were up 2.9%. Our small-container volume performance of 20 basis points includes a 40 basis point decline due to not renewing select National Accounts customers and work performed on behalf of brokers. We view these losses as non-regrettable.
The post-collection business, made up of third-party landfill and transfer station volumes, increased 5.5%. Landfill volume increased 6.8%, which includes MSW of 4.7%, C&D of 17.8% and special waste of 8.7%. While C&D collection volumes and landfill volumes were broad based geographically, we saw above average volume growth in the areas of the country that experienced milder winter conditions. At the same time, we saw heavier rainfall in certain areas of the country. In these areas, we experienced higher disposal expense due to heavier container weights and additional leachate management costs. We believe these additional costs were directly related to the wet weather and expect these costs will return to planned levels for the remainder of the year.
Third, fuel recovery fees decreased 140 basis points. The change relates to decline in the cost of fuel, which decreased approximately $23 million compared to the prior year. The average price per gallon of diesel decreased to $2.08 in the first quarter from $2.92 in the prior year, a decrease of 29%. The current average diesel price is $2.20 per gallon. We recover approximately 80% of our total fuel costs through our fuel recovery fee program. Additionally, 20% of our diesel gallons are hedged using financial hedges.
Next, energy services revenue decreased 60 basis points. The decrease in energy services revenue primarily relates to a decrease in drilling activity resulting from a decline in oil prices. The energy services revenue decline includes a    decrease in Tervita-related volumes from the date of acquisition and a decline in E&P volumes at our solid waste landfills.
Finally, commodity revenue decreased 10 basis points. The decrease in commodity sales primarily relates to a decrease in recycled commodity prices. Excluding glass and organics, average commodity prices decreased 10% to $100 per ton in the first quarter from $111 per ton in the prior year. 
First quarter total recycling volume of 621,000 tons represents an increase of approximately 7% from the prior year. Volumes were approximately 1% on a same-store basis. Cost of goods sold for recycled commodities was relatively flat with the prior year.
Now we'll discuss changes in margin. First quarter adjusted EBITDA margin was 27.8%, which compares to 28.9% in the prior year. The change includes a 50 basis point decline from the additional workday, a 20 basis point decline from net fuel and a decline of 40 basis points from an increase in health care-related expenses. Regarding the increase in health care costs, we self-insure employee medical claims. In the first quarter, we saw an increase in large claims primarily resulting from nonwork-related injuries and onetime incidents. We did not make any changes in our plan structure and our third party administrator confirmed these were not inflationary type increases. We expect health care costs to return back to planned levels for the remainder of the year. 
When looking at other cost line items as a percentage of revenue, there is an impact in the decrease in fuel recovery fees and the sale of commodity revenue. For example, the 1.5% decline in these revenues resulted in an increase in labor expense as a percentage of revenue of 30 basis points, and repairs and maintenance expense of 20 basis points. SG&A costs were 10.7% of revenue and in line with our expectations. These costs improved 30 basis points compared to the prior year. I want to remind you that we provide a detailed schedule of cost of operations and SG&A expenses in our 8-K filing.
First quarter 2016 interest expense was $93 million, which includes $12 million of noncash amortization. Our effective tax rate was approximately 38%. The lower tax rate in the first quarter reflects a $0.01 EPS benefit from settling a state tax matter. We expect an effective tax rate of approximately 39.5% for the remainder of the year. First quarter adjusted free cash flow was $160 million and in line with our expectations. During the quarter, we spent $275 million or approximately 31% of our annual projected capital expenditures. 
Now I will turn the call back over to Don.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chuck. To conclude, our first quarter results were consistent with our expectations and keep us on track to achieve our full year guidance. I'm proud of how the Republic team continue to execute our strategy of profitable growth and differentiatio
componenttext:
Thanks, Chuck. To conclude, our first quarter results were consistent with our expectations and keep us on track to achieve our full year guidance. I'm proud of how the Republic team continue to execute our strategy of profitable growth and differentiation, and our performance reflects our hard work. We will continue to deliver on our promises to our key stakeholders, including our customers, communities, employees and shareholders. 
At this time, operator, I would like to open the call to questions.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you just talk a little bit about your volumes? So I mean, we're seeing strength across not just with you, but with your peers. Can you just talk about if this surprised you in the quarter? I know there was a lot going on with milder weather and extra
componenttext: Can you just talk a little bit about your volumes? So I mean, we're seeing strength across not just with you, but with your peers. Can you just talk about if this surprised you in the quarter? I know there was a lot going on with milder weather and extra workday, but did this surprise you? And is this inflection we're seeing with strength sustainable, in your opinion?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I don't think the extra workday surprised us. The weather was certainly -- if you compare the weather in Q1 to Q1 last year, the weather was much milder, which we like. So the standard answer we tend to give in Q1 on this kind of thing is that a b
componenttext: Yes, so I don't think the extra workday surprised us. The weather was certainly -- if you compare the weather in Q1 to Q1 last year, the weather was much milder, which we like. So the standard answer we tend to give in Q1 on this kind of thing is that a big important quarter for us is Q2, Andrew, as we see there's normal seasonality return. So we know we're very happy with the trends. We know there's a lot of good construction activity going on out there that's driving our volume growth. As I said in my comments, a lot of this is kind of the event business, construction, special waste doing well. So we'd like to think it will continue into Q2. Again, the weather comp will be a little different than Q2 over last year, but there's no doubt that it's fairly robust out there.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, yes. And then I mean -- so I guess, just what you said before with your guidance for volume, and I know you had said 0.5% to 1% last quarter, but I guess, we're just waiting here on Q2 to see if it's sustainable for you guys to feel comfortable?
componenttext: Okay, yes. And then I mean -- so I guess, just what you said before with your guidance for volume, and I know you had said 0.5% to 1% last quarter, but I guess, we're just waiting here on Q2 to see if it's sustainable for you guys to feel comfortable?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, we would say that our volume guidance, we probably feel like it's going to be closer to the high end of that range based on how strong Q1 was. So that's the math you're trying to do, right? We would agree with it. Keep in mind, we gave that gui
componenttext: Yes. Look, we would say that our volume guidance, we probably feel like it's going to be closer to the high end of that range based on how strong Q1 was. So that's the math you're trying to do, right? We would agree with it. Keep in mind, we gave that guidance because we've got a little bit of lost business coming up in some of the residential contracts that we expect to lose because we couldn't negotiate reasonable rates to extend the business. So we know that's coming later in the year. That will offset a little bit, but we'll see probably volume at the higher end of the range.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you can expect to see residential volumes approximately negative 1% because of the losses that Don had talked about for the full year. And that's what brings us closer to the 1% total volume growth.
componenttext: So you can expect to see residential volumes approximately negative 1% because of the losses that Don had talked about for the full year. And that's what brings us closer to the 1% total volume growth.

Can you just give us some color on whether this conversion process is going slower or faster than you guys anticipated? And is it getting easier as you convert more?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I said in my comments, we're up to $325 million now. That's quite a bit more than 10% of our total. We were -- I think we're picking up a little bit of speed. I would say it's -- I think, we'd say it's getting easier because our people are getting
componenttext: Yes. So I said in my comments, we're up to $325 million now. That's quite a bit more than 10% of our total. We were -- I think we're picking up a little bit of speed. I would say it's -- I think, we'd say it's getting easier because our people are getting more confident in their ability to have the conversation with customers. As I probably said to you before, it's all about fairness, coming up with an escalator that both the customer and the provider can live with that's fear based on reasonable inflationary cost. So we are making headway and we'll continue to do so. I think the market's becoming more, I would say, more adjusted to it. And so we'll see how it goes through time, but we're fairly positive.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes. So defection, if we're talking about defection, that's pretty flat compared to last year. And customer churn overall is flattish, but I would say on a longer trajectory, we continue to see the benefits of pricing tools, Capture, et cetera, to help us do a better job with churn.

componenttext: Sure. So we expect right now that cost as a percentage of revenue for maintenance will decline sequentially for the remainder of the year. And then as Don had mentioned, we're making a push right now to get this One Fleet maintenance initiative all the way through the organization. So that's what's causing this to be a little bit higher on a dollar basis year-over-year.

componenttextpreview: Okay. So it sounds like it pays off more kind of as a percentage of revenue in '17. And then Chuck, real quick, can you go back over to the health care expense? So how much was it in gross dollars? And just to be clear, you're not expecting that to recur?
componenttext: Okay. So it sounds like it pays off more kind of as a percentage of revenue in '17. And then Chuck, real quick, can you go back over to the health care expense? So how much was it in gross dollars? And just to be clear, you're not expecting that to recur?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we're not expecting it to recur. It's about $9 million in terms of dollars on a year-over-year basis. When we look at the portfolio of claims that we got during the first quarter, it had to do with what we would say very unusual items. So think ab
componenttext: Yes. So we're not expecting it to recur. It's about $9 million in terms of dollars on a year-over-year basis. When we look at the portfolio of claims that we got during the first quarter, it had to do with what we would say very unusual items. So think about complications associated with implants, think about gastrointestinal infections. These aren't types of claims that we typically get. Most of our claims are musculoskeletal. This is totally unusual for us. And we talked to our experts about this and they said "Yes, it's very unusual for you. It's very unusual for companies in the transportation industry." But in their experience, on the portfolio of businesses that they look at, every once in a while, you have one of these black swan events. We continue to monitor the expenses in April, and they're actually coming down to normalized levels. And so that gives us more comfort in saying that this was a one-time blip in these claims.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tyler. You can tell by Chuck's detailed answer that we spent a lot of time digging into this claim data, right? So we think Q1 is somewhat of an anomaly here.
componenttext: Yes, Tyler. You can tell by Chuck's detailed answer that we spent a lot of time digging into this claim data, right? So we think Q1 is somewhat of an anomaly here.

Can you just address that? It looks like some working capital, things are moving around. But -- is it a lot of what you expected and should we expect the seasonality to be different this year?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so absolutely in line with what we have expected. When you look at it quarter-over-quarter, you've got about $70 [ph] million more CapEx during our 2016 than we had in 2015. That's associated with some truck purchases that we made, having to do with
componenttext: Yes, so absolutely in line with what we have expected. When you look at it quarter-over-quarter, you've got about $70 [ph] million more CapEx during our 2016 than we had in 2015. That's associated with some truck purchases that we made, having to do with some contracts in Northern California. And then we had some working capital items also. So the timing of payroll, we actually had an extra payroll during the quarter. Also, higher incentive compensation that was paid during the quarter versus last year. So all timing related and still feel very comfortable with our annual guidance of $820 million to $840 million.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Corey, one of the ways you may want to think of it, too, is if you take a look at the $160 million that we reported in the first quarter, if you normalized the CapEx, so had we only purchased 25% of our full year guidance, that would have added $50 mi
componenttext: And Corey, one of the ways you may want to think of it, too, is if you take a look at the $160 million that we reported in the first quarter, if you normalized the CapEx, so had we only purchased 25% of our full year guidance, that would have added $50 million to our performance, which would have put us around $210 million. You can do the math on that and see what that extrapolates to the year.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe my second question, also on the cost side, did I understand, Chuck, could you say that fuel was a net negative to margin? Can you just repeat that? And then is the full benefit of taking out the layer of management, was that in Q1 or
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe my second question, also on the cost side, did I understand, Chuck, could you say that fuel was a net negative to margin? Can you just repeat that? And then is the full benefit of taking out the layer of management, was that in Q1 or should we expect some initial -- some more cost reduction in Q2 versus Q1?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So in terms of the impact of the net fuel on margins, it was about 20 basis points of the negative. So keep in mind that what you're doing is you're pulling that rate revenue off, and so it's having an adverse impact on the margins overall. So that
componenttext: Okay. So in terms of the impact of the net fuel on margins, it was about 20 basis points of the negative. So keep in mind that what you're doing is you're pulling that rate revenue off, and so it's having an adverse impact on the margins overall. So that was about 20 basis points. In terms of the initiative, during the quarter, we had about $3 million of savings. We expect that to go up maybe closer to $5 million to $6 million of savings on a quarterly basis. But also keep in mind that what we had guided to was the fact that we would have some initiative investments during the year that would offset that. So I would say that right now, we're right on track in terms of our initiatives savings or realignment savings.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: And the next question will come from Joe Box of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just want to dig into the margin a little bit further. Your EBITDA margins are down 110 basis points, and if you add back the extra day, which is 50 basis points, it sounds like 40 or so basis points from health care problems, call it about a 20 basi
componenttext: So I just want to dig into the margin a little bit further. Your EBITDA margins are down 110 basis points, and if you add back the extra day, which is 50 basis points, it sounds like 40 or so basis points from health care problems, call it about a 20 basis point headwind. I'm just curious, if you were to normalize some of those other elevated expenses, whether it's leachate or disposal cost, where do you think that EBITDA margin would have shaken out, then?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's think about it this way, Joe. If you look at the EBITDA margin that we reported, 27.8%, add back to your point 40 basis points for the health expense. And then keep in mind that during Q1, you had your seasonally highest SG&A, so we're at 10.7% vers
componenttext: Let's think about it this way, Joe. If you look at the EBITDA margin that we reported, 27.8%, add back to your point 40 basis points for the health expense. And then keep in mind that during Q1, you had your seasonally highest SG&A, so we're at 10.7% versus our guidance of about 10.5% for the year. That's another 20 basis points. So a total of 60 basis points. Add that back to the 27.8% and you get 28.4%, which is right in line with our guidance for the year.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Let me switch gears to the recycling side. Can you maybe talk to how long it might take to adapt this fee-based recycling model? And maybe what current recycling prices are? How out of whack do you think the revenues are relative to your processing cost? I'm just trying to understand what the overall benefit could be as this gets absorbed into the system.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, starting out, let's back up to recent year highs in recycling. Today, we're down over like $120 million of...
componenttext: Well, starting out, let's back up to recent year highs in recycling. Today, we're down over like $120 million of...

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, $70 a ton.
componenttext: Yes, $70 a ton.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, right. So that's what we were enjoying, whatever it was 7 or 8 years ago, right. So we realigned the organization, as we said, to really focus on getting better profitability cost structure. And on the processing side, those folks are doing a great j
componenttext: Yes, right. So that's what we were enjoying, whatever it was 7 or 8 years ago, right. So we realigned the organization, as we said, to really focus on getting better profitability cost structure. And on the processing side, those folks are doing a great job with that. We need to migrate that over to the collections side now and into some of the hauling contracts. It's going to take a little while. We probably have some routes out there that aren't dense enough that may never have enough participation or density to make sense. So we're going to be addressing that in the open market certainly and maybe even some other contractual stuff. We've got to make more headway with our municipal partners. And as I said in my comments, we've got some examples, where we're negotiating glass surcharges. We're taking glass out. We're changing the rebate structure, the fee-based, et cetera. So we're getting better at it, but we're very, very early innings. I think we're much further along in moving of the municipal contracts to the new index. We've got more momentum there. We're breathing some fire now into the recycling collection business to move those contracts. I don't know how long this is going to take, Joe. It's going to depend a little bit on how the -- what the market dynamic is. But we're not going to be caught with getting drunk again on high commodity prices, right? We've got to fix the business for good, get to the right sharing with our customer base. As I always say and I said in my comments, sustainability doesn't work without profitability. That's what we're focused on, and we're not going to do business that has a diminishing return. So...

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will come from Michael Hoffman of Stifel.
componenttext: The next question will come from Michael Hoffman of Stifel.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So back to the CPI. At one point over the last couple of years, you had described the sort of pool of addressable revenues at about $2 billion. What do you think of the practical number that can be converted on a percentage basis? And where I'm going with
componenttext: So back to the CPI. At one point over the last couple of years, you had described the sort of pool of addressable revenues at about $2 billion. What do you think of the practical number that can be converted on a percentage basis? And where I'm going with that is it would be a good thing if you got some number and then inflation comes back to 2%, and when the two blend together, you're net ahead of the game.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So again, with everybody listening, hopefully a lot of my teammates at Republic, right, we absolutely positively can't be entering into contracts with escalators that don't keep pace with our net inflation, inflation net of productivity. We got to
componenttext: Right. So again, with everybody listening, hopefully a lot of my teammates at Republic, right, we absolutely positively can't be entering into contracts with escalators that don't keep pace with our net inflation, inflation net of productivity. We got to be equal or better, right? And as I've said many times, right, for decades, as long as I've been around, that CPI work great, it was fair, we need to get fairness again. And so my viewpoint is all contracts have to be converted to a metric or an escalator that's fair and reasonable. And so we're tackling this space. We said -- look, we've got $2.5 billion of the business. About $800 million of that $2.5 billion is the smaller contracts. That's where we went to work first. Now we've got $325 million that's converted. Now we're working toward bigger contracts. And we're, right now, as we speak, talking to customers, some very large customers about this very thing. And I think, at some point, we'll have made some of those conversions successful and the market will continue to move. So if you take a look at our pricing, this quarter, a 2% yield. We've been north of 2 now for a few quarters. What keeps holding that back down is residential. And so we're very, very close to hitting this overarching metric for us of getting back to a day where yield surpasses inflation on a regular and consistent basis. So we're right on the cusp of that. And so we're going to keep pushing the new metric. I don't have an exact day, date in mind when we can get there. I know we're making progress, Michael, and we're -- you can tell by the determination in my voice that we're kind of at a place where we're not taking no for an answer because we just can't be in a situation where we have these large contracts with a lot of exposure and declining returns. It's just not -- it's not feasible or it's not practical.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, fair enough. Switching gears to margin trend. If I took your 50 basis points for adjustment to your gross margin, so instead of doing 38.6%, you did 39.1% for the first quarter. Given how good the volume was and when possibly some of it got pul
componenttext: All right, fair enough. Switching gears to margin trend. If I took your 50 basis points for adjustment to your gross margin, so instead of doing 38.6%, you did 39.1% for the first quarter. Given how good the volume was and when possibly some of it got pulled forward, is it probable that the gross margin in 2Q might trend down a little bit? I mean 20, 25 basis points? And really, what you want to look at is smoothing the first half and comparing that to the first half of '15.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think so, Michael. I think that -- I don't know that we necessarily need to smooth this. Part of the noise that I think that we might be seeing in the first quarter has to do with the workday. And we need to keep in mind that, that reverses in
componenttext: No, I don't think so, Michael. I think that -- I don't know that we necessarily need to smooth this. Part of the noise that I think that we might be seeing in the first quarter has to do with the workday. And we need to keep in mind that, that reverses in Q4, so there's going to be a little pickup there when that happens. But I would say that right now, we feel pretty comfortable with our adjusted EBITDA margin guidance that we gave, the 28.5% for the year.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. I wasn't disputing that. I was just really, like, trying to figure out, given how strong volumes were in the first quarter and the operating leverage that comes from that, in all likelihood, those volumes remained good, but not as good as 1Q be
componenttext: Yes, okay. I wasn't disputing that. I was just really, like, trying to figure out, given how strong volumes were in the first quarter and the operating leverage that comes from that, in all likelihood, those volumes remained good, but not as good as 1Q because of the positive circumstances. And therefore, you might see a slight shift in margin 1Q to the next. It's not a bad thing if you smooth the 2 Qs together, you've got the objective you were trying to achieve anyway, but you've pulled some of that benefit into 1Q. So you're -- go ahead, sorry.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was going to say -- Michael, this is Brian. So remember the largest percentage of our volume growth was in the roll-off business, which was up about 13%. And as you know, that comes along with the variable cost, so I know you were talking about leverage
componenttext: I was going to say -- Michael, this is Brian. So remember the largest percentage of our volume growth was in the roll-off business, which was up about 13%. And as you know, that comes along with the variable cost, so I know you were talking about leverage, but that's where we saw the concentration of volume. But the other thing is that we know that while it was a mild winter, in parts of the country, it was also wet, right? So we did see extra operating cost. We saw higher disposal expense where we've got predominantly third-party disposal markets, and we saw some additional leachate expense, again, where it was wet. So from a weather perspective, it's not that we feel like we've got a whole lot of contribution to the bottom line from the mild winter. So if the revenues fall off a little bit in the second quarter because maybe they were pulled forward, we would also expect some of the cost to taper off as well.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough.
componenttext: Okay, fair enough.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, to us, and sometimes, the answer is timing and mix, Michael, right? That's kind of what Brian said. But you're right, I mean, I think the quarter was very strong. And if you take out some of the anomalies, call it just health care and some of this le
componenttext: Yes, to us, and sometimes, the answer is timing and mix, Michael, right? That's kind of what Brian said. But you're right, I mean, I think the quarter was very strong. And if you take out some of the anomalies, call it just health care and some of this leachate expense and some of that stuff, I mean, I look at it like we had a $0.50 [ph] quarter. So we've got a little bit of noise with a few items and we've got a little bit of, as Chuck described with the residential volume, we got a couple of blips on the horizon there with some contracts we'll walk away from. We talked in the comments about some volume, non-regrettable volumes loss with National Accounts and brokers. So there's some other noise in the system, but we're really confident in the guidance and in the margin, and more importantly, in the actions we're taking and the way that the team is executing. So...

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Michael, maybe to your question, as Chuck kind of mentioned, second half probably looks better than first half because in the second half, we have 1 less workday, whereas in the first half, we add the 1 more. So maybe that's the way you want to think
componenttext: And Michael, maybe to your question, as Chuck kind of mentioned, second half probably looks better than first half because in the second half, we have 1 less workday, whereas in the first half, we add the 1 more. So maybe that's the way you want to think about it.

componenttext: Yes, we've set out the year with a target of spending $100 million and spending that $100 million again primarily in tuck-ins and primarily within the same EBITDA range that we had over the last couple of years. And we still, today, think that we'll accomplish that goal. We've got a little slow start here on the year, but we think we'll exit the year having very wisely spent $100 million and invested it in some really good tuck-in assets.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. Last question from me, if I may. You mentioned higher leachate cost. One of your competitors also talked about it today on their call. Are there any sizable investments that you expect related to this issue?
componenttext: That's helpful. Last question from me, if I may. You mentioned higher leachate cost. One of your competitors also talked about it today on their call. Are there any sizable investments that you expect related to this issue?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, not really. For us, when we look at leachate, it's been somewhat unique to the individual landfill. I mean, it really is about the geology of individual landfills and also the weather that exists, whether it's a dry climate or a wet. Obviously, in the
componenttext: No, not really. For us, when we look at leachate, it's been somewhat unique to the individual landfill. I mean, it really is about the geology of individual landfills and also the weather that exists, whether it's a dry climate or a wet. Obviously, in the southwest, we don't have a lot of leachate. We don't have a lot of rain. We have airy climates and the water evaporates. We've got some landfills that have in gradient water flows that we've got to deal with, so that's a little bit of a different issue. So it really is site-specific. The leachate cost that we saw in Q1 was really more about a wet, a seasonally wet, an unusually, seasonally wet quarter. Having said that, landfills are more expensive to own and operate every day and every year and we're constantly evaluating our cost structure and constantly looking for ways to effectively pass along the price increases into the market that makes sense to capture the cost inflation. We've got to manage these things responsibly and be good environmental stewards and we'll continue to do that. But for us, leachate is really more of a site-specific issue, but that's all I can tell you it as we look at the quarter. There's nothing else for us really going on broadly with our leachate story.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from Michael Feniger of Bank of America.
componenttext: And the next question will come from Michael Feniger of Bank of America.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Did you guys see any changes through the quarter and April when you're speaking about special event volume, C&D? Anything that makes you -- any cause for a concern, that the momentum you felt on the volume side would slow going into the second quarter?
componenttext: Did you guys see any changes through the quarter and April when you're speaking about special event volume, C&D? Anything that makes you -- any cause for a concern, that the momentum you felt on the volume side would slow going into the second quarter?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, no. I think, specifically, construction volume is strong, one, because of the unusual weather. But Q2 is where we tend to see the seasonal pickups and we certainly expect to see that. Event business in the special waste business was strong in Q1. Th
componenttext: Well, no. I think, specifically, construction volume is strong, one, because of the unusual weather. But Q2 is where we tend to see the seasonal pickups and we certainly expect to see that. Event business in the special waste business was strong in Q1. There's no concern that we have there overall. I mean, we're still only at 1.1 million new home starts. Single-family home starts are actually up, right, on a year-over-year basis. So that bodes well for us. We tend to lag that. So as long as that continues, I think, that's what drives more and more growth in our markets. So on a total macro basis, we're feeling really, really good.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the loss of the residential business that you guys were discussing, should we be thinking that as a positive for the mix? Would that be positive to margin?
componenttext: And the loss of the residential business that you guys were discussing, should we be thinking that as a positive for the mix? Would that be positive to margin?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, ultimately -- look, residential is our weakest line of business in our collection system, right? And you think about the state of affairs there that we've had the sustainable CPI environment for how many years?
componenttext: Yes. Well, ultimately -- look, residential is our weakest line of business in our collection system, right? And you think about the state of affairs there that we've had the sustainable CPI environment for how many years?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: 6, 7 years.
componenttext: 6, 7 years.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: 6, 7 years. It's averaged over that time 1.6%, right? Our cost don't average 1.6% so you can just sort of do some math and figure out what kind of margin erosion we've had there in that space. That's why we're so adamant about changing the indices to some
componenttext: 6, 7 years. It's averaged over that time 1.6%, right? Our cost don't average 1.6% so you can just sort of do some math and figure out what kind of margin erosion we've had there in that space. That's why we're so adamant about changing the indices to something that's fair and reasonable. So we get to a do a negotiation with a residential customer, who can't seem to understand that degree of fairness. We can't enter into extending contracts that continue to decline and go below our reasonable rate of return. So ultimately, we have to grow the ROI in the business. And so your point is yes, over time, that's a good thing. We either have to shed business that doesn't equal the right return or we have to get a pricing scenario that is reasonable for both parties, so. And that's the story. It's the same story with National Accounts and some of the broker business, right?

componenttext: Well, generally speaking, the business is performing somewhat like we thought it would. We knew it would be weaker this year than maybe we thought when we started the business. But we budgeted essentially for that, probably a little bit weaker overall, but we -- I think the thing that we always want to point out is we think ultimately, through the cycle, that business is going to come back and perform well for the company.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from Al Kaschalk of Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: And the next question will come from Al Kaschalk of Wedbush Securities.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, I joined late, so -- but I wanted to focus on really, I guess, 2 areas: One, you talked a little bit about the leachate and maybe you can just take a step back and help us appreciate. Is this more focused or more of a concern to companies that have
componenttext: Sorry, I joined late, so -- but I wanted to focus on really, I guess, 2 areas: One, you talked a little bit about the leachate and maybe you can just take a step back and help us appreciate. Is this more focused or more of a concern to companies that have higher number of closed landfills than, say, maybe where storms or other things could occur and, therefore, water could increase? Can you just talk a little bit about that? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as I've said in my comments earlier, leachate is really 2 things. I mean, it's -- we talked about it being site-specific. It's really about geology and weather, right? If you have a large -- if you have a large landfill with a big open space that's
componenttext: Well, as I've said in my comments earlier, leachate is really 2 things. I mean, it's -- we talked about it being site-specific. It's really about geology and weather, right? If you have a large -- if you have a large landfill with a big open space that's not covered, right, then you get a lot of rainfall. All that rainfall goes into your landfill and becomes leachate, okay? if you are in an airy climate where you don't have leachate or don't have rainfall, you don't have that problem, right? So it's very site-specific. And again, as we have a lot of rainfall in certain parts of the country and in certain parts of the year, we have snow normally. Snow tends to fall and sit on top of the landfill and then evaporate before it melts. Rainfall tends to get inside your landfill, right? So I'm not a weatherman, but that's kind of how it works, Al. So we have a number of closed landfills certainly. Some of those are so closed that they're inert, right, and there's virtually no leachate coming out of them, right? So once you complete capped the landfill and then see that completely closed state, there's no more rainwater getting in the landfill, right? So it's just about the timing, I guess, when it comes to that point. So for us, we don't have, from our perspective, as I said in an earlier question, a broad-based concern about leachate today. We have some specific sites that saw more leachate in the quarter because of rainfall, and we're dealing with that through normal operating expense.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: So again, our leachate expense was normal across the company with the exception of those sites that saw a much higher level of rainfall than normal and -- or potentially a landfill that was in the midst of construction and had a rainfall event while part of the landfill was open where normally, it wouldn't be. But other than that, our leachate expense across the company net of those landfills is just inflating at what would be a normal inflation rate. And so we generally, we -- to your pricing question, we generally deal with leachate expense and the cost of leachate expense through our environmental recovery fee with our landfill customers, right? And so over time, we raised our environmental recovery fee to deal with certain issues like leachate expense, and we've done that very effectively over recent years. And customers seem to understand that, so that's been our mechanism to deal with it.
