headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Republic Services Second Quarter 2016 Investor Conference Call. Republic Services is traded on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol RSG. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I woul
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the Republic Services Second Quarter 2016 Investor Conference Call. Republic Services is traded on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol RSG. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over the Brian DelGhiaccio, Senior Vice President of Finance.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. I would like to welcome everyone to Republic Services second quarter 2016 conference call. Don Slager, our CEO; and Chuck Serianni, our CFO, are joining me as we discuss our performance. I would like to take
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. I would like to welcome everyone to Republic Services second quarter 2016 conference call. Don Slager, our CEO; and Chuck Serianni, our CFO, are joining me as we discuss our performance. 
I would like to take a moment to remind everyone that some of the information we discuss on today's call contains forward-looking statements, which involve risks and uncertainties and may be materially different from actual results. Our SEC filings discuss factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from expectations. 
The material that we discuss today is time sensitive. if in the future, you listen to a rebroadcast or recording of this conference call, you should be sensitive to the date of the original call, which is July 28, 2016. Please note that this call is the property of Republic Services, Inc. Any redistribution, retransmission or rebroadcast of this call in any form without the express written consent of Republic Services is strictly prohibited. 
I want to point out that our SEC filings, our earnings press release, which includes GAAP reconciliation tables, and the discussion of business activities, along with a recording of this call, are all available on Republic's website at republicservices.com. And finally, I want to remind you that Republic's management team routinely participates in investor conferences. When events are scheduled, the dates, times and presentations are posted on our website. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Don.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brian. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. We are pleased with our second quarter results, which are in line with our expectations and keep us well positioned to achieve our full year financial guidance. We continue to realize
componenttext:
Thanks, Brian. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. We are pleased with our second quarter results, which are in line with our expectations and keep us well positioned to achieve our full year financial guidance. We continue to realize the benefits of executing our strategy of profitable growth through differentiation, which allows us to attract and retain higher-value customers, build the best team, increase profitability and create long-term value. 
During the second quarter, adjusted EPS was $0.55. EPS improved from the prior year even with a $0.02 increase in the effective tax rate. Excluding the increases in taxes, EPS grew approximately 6%. Adjusted free cash flow grew 5% to $177 million and was in line with our expectations. 
Core price was 3.1% and average yield was 2%. We expect average yield to remain relatively consistent with our second quarter performance for the remainder of the year. We continue to see a highest level of average yield in our small-container commercial business. A majority of these customers are in open markets, where we can leverage and increase our demand for service, our enhanced product offerings and our digital platform. 
Second quarter volumes grew -- increased -- second quarter volumes increased 50 basis points. As expected, volume growth moderated from the first quarter, but remained positive. We continue to expect volume growth of approximately 1% for the year, consistent with our guidance. Cost of operations improved 20 basis points to 61.3% of revenue from 61.5% in the prior year. There was a sequential improvement in most cost categories, including labor, maintenance and landfill operating cost. 
Adjusted EBITDA margin was consistent with the prior year at 28.3% of revenue. We incurred approximately $5 million of legal settlement cost during the quarter, which impacted EBITDA margin by 20 basis points and reduced EPS by approximately $0.01. We saw EBITDA margin improvement in all lines of business with the exception of residential. Pricing in the residential business continues to be impacted by below CPI environment. 
We launched and priced a tender transaction and new debt issuance, which will reduce annual interest cost by $17 million or approximately $0.03 of EPS. These deals closed in early July. 
As part of our efficient capital allocation strategy, we returned approximately $400 million total cash to our shareholders since the beginning of the year. This includes 4.2 million shares of repurchase for a $194 million. Additionally, our board recently raised the quarterly dividend by approximately 7%. The annualized dividend is now $1.28 per share. 
Regarding our revenue enhancing and customer-facing initiatives, first, we now have approximately $340 million in annual revenue that uses a waste-related index for the annual price adjustment. These waste indices are more closely aligned with our cost structure and have consistently ran higher than CPI. Additionally, we move $25 million in annual revenue to a fixed rate increase of 3% or greater. We made these changes for customers that want more certainly around future rate increases, and we are confident that we can manage our cost structure at or below this level. 
Second, approximately 1.6 million customers are enrolled in our customer portal and mobile app, up 60% [ph] from the prior year. This tool significantly enhance our customer interaction and connectivity. 
Third, our e-comm commerce platform now has the capability for customers to purchase temporary large container and residential subscription services online. This addresses the evolving needs of our customers' buying preferences and provides a lower-cost sales channel. Approximately 15% of residential subscription sales are coming through our e-commerce platform. 
And finally, we opened our second Customer Resource Center located in Phoenix. We expect to open our last Customer Resource Center in Indianapolis later this year. 
Regarding our fleet-based productivity and cost savings initiatives, 17% of our total fleet now operates on natural gas; 73% [ph] of our residential fleet was drilling automated; and 85% of our total fleet has been certified under our One Fleet standardized maintenance program, up from 70% [ph] a year ago. We recently completed the final wave of our One Fleet implementations and expect the entire fleet will be certified by mid-2017. 
Recent recycled commodity prices have trended above the prior year by approximately $5 to $10 per ton. If prices remain at these levels for the balance of the year, we would expect to achieve the higher end of our EPS and free cash flow guidance ranges. When assessing other macro conditions, we continue to see a gradual improvement in the fundamentals the impact our business, which was a premise for our 2016 business plan. 
Chuck will now discuss our financial results. Chuck?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don. Second quarter 2016 revenue was approximately $2.4 billion, an increase of $39 million or 1.7% over the prior year. This 1.7% increase in revenue includes internal growth of 1.3% and acquisitions of 40 basis points. The components of internal
componenttext:
Thanks, Don. Second quarter 2016 revenue was approximately $2.4 billion, an increase of $39 million or 1.7% over the prior year. This 1.7% increase in revenue includes internal growth of 1.3% and acquisitions of 40 basis points. The components of internal growth are as follows: first, total average yield growth of 2%. Average yield in the collection business was 2.3%, which includes 3.7% yield in the small-container business, 1.9% yield in the large-container business and 1.2% yield in the residential business. Average yield in the post-collection business was 1.1%, which includes landfill MSW of 1.6%. A majority of our landfill MSW business is with municipal customers that have contracts that contain pricing restrictions. Total core price, which measures price increases less rollbacks was 3.1%. Core price consisted of 4.1% in the open market and 1.5% in the restricted portion of our business. 
Second, our total volumes increased 50 basis points, which was in line with our expectations. Volume growth moderated during the second quarter, mostly due to the mild winter conditions, which favorably impacted our first quarter performance. Volumes in the collection business increased 30 basis points, which included 2.9% increase from the large-container business, a 10 basis point decline from the small-container business and a 1.4% decline from the residential business. 
Within our large-container business, temporary C&D halls were up 6.5% and recurring halls were up 2.1%. Temporary C&D halls remain strong and continue to reflect an increase in construction-related activity. 
There was a 50 basis point impact to small-container  volume from not renewing select National Accounts customers and shedding certain work performed on behalf of brokers. We view these losses as non-regrettable. 
Our residential volume decline of 1.4% was due to not renewing certain contracts that did not meet our return criteria. These losses were known and contemplated in our full year volume guidance. The post-collection business, made up of third-party landfill and transfer station volumes, increased to 1.5%. Landfill volume increased 1.6%, which consisted of MSW volume growth of 2.2% and C&D of 13.8%, partially offset by declines and landfill special waste of 1.1%. The decline in special waste relates to large event-driven volumes in the prior year that did not repeat. 
Third, fuel recovery fees decreased 1%. The change primarily relates to decline in the cost of. fuel. The average price we're down as diesel decreased $2.30 in the second quarter from $2.85 in the prior year, a decrease of 19%. The current average diesel price is $2.38 per gallon. 
We recovered approximately 80% of our total fuel costs through our fuel recovery fee program. Additionally, 20% of our diesel gallons are hedged using financial hedges. 
Next, energy services revenue decreased 50 basis points. The decrease in energy services revenue primarily relates to a year-over-year decreased in drilling activity resulting from a decline in the price of oil. 
Finally, commodity revenue increased 30 basis points. The increase in commodity revenue primarily relates to an increase in processing fees charged to third parties. This increase results from our initiative to transition to fee-based recycling model. Excluding glass and organics, average commodity prices increased 3% to $116 per ton in the second quarter from $113 per ton in the prior year. Second quarter total recycling volume of 648,000 [ph] tons was consistent with the prior year. Cost of goods sold for recycled commodities was flat versus the prior year. 
Now I will discuss changes in margin. Second quarter adjusted EBITDA margin was 28.3% and consistent with the prior year. Total cost of operations decreased to 61.3% from 61.5% in the prior year, resulting in 20 basis points of margin expansion. Sequentially, the year-over-year change in labor improved 30 basis points and maintenance improved 40 basis points. We expect maintenance expense as a percentage of revenue will be below prior year levels as we exit the year. 
SG&A expenses were 10.4% of revenue compared to 10.2% in the prior year. The 20 basis point increase was due to settling certain legal matters from prior years. On a full year basis, we expect SG&A expenses of 10.5% of revenue, which represents a 30 basis point improvement from 2015. 
When looking at the detailed cost line items as a percentage of revenue, there is an impact from the decrease in fuel recovery fees. For example, the 1% decline in fuel recovery fee revenue resulted in an increase in labor expense of 20 basis points and repairs and maintenance expense of 10 basis points. I want to remind you that we provide a detailed schedule of cost of operations and SG&A expenses in our 8-K filing. 
Second quarter 2016 interest expense was $92 million, which included $12 million in noncash amortization. As Don mentioned, we recently completed several financing transactions. First, we refinanced our $1 billion credit facility that was maturing in May of 2017. Second, we standard $575 million of debt with coupons ranging from 5.7% to 7.4%. And finally, we issued $500 million of 10-year senior notes with a 2.9% coupon. As a result of these transactions, we expect to save approximately $17 million in annual interest expense or approximately $0.03 of EPS. 
Our effective tax rate was approximately 38%. The lower tax rate in the second quarter resulted in a $0.01 EPS benefit from settling a federal tax matter. We expect an effective tax rate of approximately 39.5% for the remainder of the year. 
Second quarter adjusted free cash flow was $177 million and year-to-date adjusted free cash flow was $337 million. Both were in line with our expectations. We expect free cash flow generation will be weighted to the second half of the year due to the timing of capital expenditures and working capital. We remain comfortable with our full year adjusted free cash flow guidance of $820 million to $840 million. 
Now we'll turn the call back over to Don.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chuck. To conclude, our second quarter results were consistent with our expectations and keeps us on track to achieve our full year guidance. I'm proud of how the Republic team continued to execute our strategy of profitable growth through differe
componenttext:
Thanks, Chuck. To conclude, our second quarter results were consistent with our expectations and keeps us on track to achieve our full year guidance. I'm proud of how the Republic team continued to execute our strategy of profitable growth through differentiation, and our performance continues to reflect our hard work. We will continue to deliver on our promises to our key stakeholders, including our customers, communities, employees and shareholders. 
At this time of the call, I would like to open the call to questions.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Tyler Brown of Raymond James.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Tyler Brown of Raymond James.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Core pricing did decelerate a little bit, but yield has held steady. I think, the spread between the 2 is about as small as we've seen in some time. I know one of your competitors have talked about much improved churn. I'm just curious if you're experienc
componenttext: Core pricing did decelerate a little bit, but yield has held steady. I think, the spread between the 2 is about as small as we've seen in some time. I know one of your competitors have talked about much improved churn. I'm just curious if you're experiencing the same? And can you talk a little bit about how PBS and Capture may be helping out there?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Certainly, what we're seeing here is a benefit from PBS and from Capture, and that's what allowed us to decrease that churn by about 30 basis points sequentially. The other thing that we have here, Tyler, is the fact that we're very much focused on e
componenttext: Yes. Certainly, what we're seeing here is a benefit from PBS and from Capture, and that's what allowed us to decrease that churn by about 30 basis points sequentially. The other thing that we have here, Tyler, is the fact that we're very much focused on ensuring that we're charging for all of the services that we perform, and that would include things like delivery fees and extra pick up. So that's really the focus that we placed on these new tools and on charging for the services has really allowed us to drive down that churn.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tyler, this is Don. As you know, PBS is fully rolled out. Capture has now been rolled out for some time. The adoption rates, utilization rates for those tools are very high. We've got great trending programs in place to retrain new hires. It's been really
componenttext: Tyler, this is Don. As you know, PBS is fully rolled out. Capture has now been rolled out for some time. The adoption rates, utilization rates for those tools are very high. We've got great trending programs in place to retrain new hires. It's been really a great success for us. There's a lot of pull in the organization for those kinds of tools, professionalizing the sales team. As a backdrop to what Chuck said, the section has remained low at 7% and now we've had that low for a long time. Churn is improving, as Chuck said. The underlying fundamentals of small-container business is strong. So just all around good steady business and really good execution by the sales organization. And year-over-year, look at cost or price of new sales compared of new sales from last year is lup off and that's, again, due to the new tools that we've got out there

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's extremely helpful. Chuck, this is a bigger picture question, but margins have been hanging around this 28% range for, I would say, the past couple of years. I know, probably, you guys have talked about that there's really nothing structurally
componenttext: Okay. That's extremely helpful. Chuck, this is a bigger picture question, but margins have been hanging around this 28% range for, I would say, the past couple of years. I know, probably, you guys have talked about that there's really nothing structurally that precludes you from getting back to, say, that 30% margin profile. I know there's lots of internal initiatives, but what are the real key levers to getting back to that range? Is it really about bending the cost curve? Or do you guys need some exogenous help from, say, CPI commodities? Is that what's going to help you get there?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, when we think about it longer term, we will need to be successful in terms of switching our customers from CPI to some of the pricing index, which we're very much focused in on. Obviously, a little bit of a tailwind from commodity pricing would h
componenttext: I think, when we think about it longer term, we will need to be successful in terms of switching our customers from CPI to some of the pricing index, which we're very much focused in on. Obviously, a little bit of a tailwind from commodity pricing would help us also. But we are beginning to see margin expansion, right? So we had gross margin expansion during the quarter at 20 basis points as I mentioned. The other thing is we still feel comfortable saying that we're going to have growth or EBITDA margin expansion during the year. Part of that is going to come from just our continual focus on cost, including maintenance and labor. And also, we're going to get a little bit of a benefit from the reversal of the workday. So we feel really good about the progress that we're making this year in terms of the cost side of the equation, and we feel good about being able to get back to the 30% margins.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Remember, last time, we were north of 30%, Tyler. and we've been as high as 31%-ish. We had better recycling commodity prices. We had -- we did not have the CPI environments. Those were 2 important macro things that you pointed out. But we are now se
componenttext: Yes. Remember, last time, we were north of 30%, Tyler. and we've been as high as 31%-ish. We had better recycling commodity prices. We had -- we did not have the CPI environments. Those were 2 important macro things that you pointed out. But we are now seeing benefits coming through the P&L from the 1 [ph] [indiscernible] initiative that's fully rolled out, as I said and certify everybody by this time next year. That's starting to pay dividends. We'll see the benefits start to happen next year and in '18 from the benefit of the reorg net of the CIC consolidations. Those start to roll in. Those are, I think, costs that will easily be able to achieve based on what we've seen so far. So there's a lot of good things in the works, and then again, there's always the next we've initiatives that we haven't talked about yet.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Noah Kaye of Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Noah Kaye of Oppenheimer.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just start with the recycling part of the business. First of all, can you just remind us how far you are through that process of reworking that contract? And how long do think that will take? And I think as a second part of that question would be,
componenttext: Let me just start with the recycling part of the business. First of all, can you just remind us how far you are through that process of reworking that contract? And how long do think that will take? And I think as a second part of that question would be, is I think, in particular, you put in place some pretty state-of-the-art automation on some of your segment facilities. To what extent are you seeing that high automation level helping you on the margin profile and helping the economics of that?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. So let me start just by reminding everybody that the recycling business really is unique based on individual markets. So while on one hand, we continue to make strong investments in recycling and we are very much committed to helping our customers
componenttext: Great. So let me start just by reminding everybody that the recycling business really is unique based on individual markets. So while on one hand, we continue to make strong investments in recycling and we are very much committed to helping our customers do the right thing for the planet and to meet their sustainability goals, that only works for us in markets where customers are willing to pay for the service and where we've got enough density and participation to make it work. So I see very often the sustainability doesn't work without profitability, and those are a couple of key issues. Customers really need to evaluate and we need to have density and participation to make it work. So while we made some great state-of-the-art investments, as you pointed out, we've won some awards, frankly, for some of our innovation in and around recycling. At the same time, we've also had to close some low-volume facilities that were antiquated and where we don't have enough participation to make recycling where it can't work as a loss leader. So half or are we in the process of really reinventing a reimagining recycling? It's -- again, if you think about our business being only about 10% of revenue in recycling, one of the most volatile parts of our business has been, as we just spoke to Tyler about the commodity pricing environment, while it's starting to move up a little bit, it started of very low in the year. Maybe it's going to come back even stronger the second half, we'll have to see. But 2 components of recycling. One is processing, where we take in material to our facilities from third parties. And then 1 is collection. On the processing side, about 40% of the volume we take in for processing, we've adjusted or had to have favorable terms. So for those customers to actually share in the risk and the upside of the material in the market prices. So those are good contracts. The remaining 18% of those customers in the process inside of our business or remaining customers are going to come due for renegotiation over the 18 months. So over the next 18 months, we'll negotiate to get to fair terms of there. And then on the collections side, that really besides primarily in our residential municipal business, and we're working with our municipal partners to help understand this issue and we are renegotiating contracts as we go through time. Those contracts and to be longer term, so I would say we're just still very -- in the very early innings with that. But most of the dialogue has been met with the kind of practical solutions, and people understand that it's got to work for both sides of the partnership. So we're just going to continue to work through it and continue to invest where it makes sense.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. I'd like to ask you a question on the relationship between increasing customer profitability and some of the technology initiatives that you're adopting. And you mentioned that you're seeing good progress on customer churn continuing to trend lower
componenttext: Great. I'd like to ask you a question on the relationship between increasing customer profitability and some of the technology initiatives that you're adopting. And you mentioned that you're seeing good progress on customer churn continuing to trend lower. I would also think, with some of the fairly advanced probably magic and optimization technologies that you've got, it's becoming easier to pinpoint the types of accounts that will improve raw density and integrate greater profitability. So to what extent should we continue to expect that to be a tailwind for you as basically as secular technologies [indiscernible]?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, just to be clear, we've been using route-based technology or computer-based technology for routing for a long time, right? And GPS type systems and geo coding, that's not new technology for us. We will continue to improve the utilization of those sy
componenttext: Well, just to be clear, we've been using route-based technology or computer-based technology for routing for a long time, right? And GPS type systems and geo coding, that's not new technology for us. We will continue to improve the utilization of those systems. But that's not going to be a bigger lever for us to pull. We're just going to get incrementally better year-on-year and continue to sort of improve as the tools improved. But we've been using those tools for a long time, so I don't want to leave the impression that our routes are highly inefficient or densely routed because that's one of the reasons our margins are 28%, because the of the density model in our business.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Andrew Buscaglia of Crdit Suisse.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Can you just talk about -- I thought your topline was a little bit -- it was a touch less than and I was expecting. And if you break it down, it looks like, I think, expectations may have been a little bit high from Q1 but on the volume side. But they're pretty much online, although there is some interesting puts and takes when you start breaking down the volume. Can you just talk about each or the ones that -- are the ones that would your expectations or maybe were a little bit later? I know there's a lot going on with comps and...

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we'll take it. Let's start out by starting in context, right? We had a pretty strong volume growth rate in Q1 but we reminded everybody that was kind of a strange comp year-over-year. We've got a very mild winter compared with a very tough winter the
componenttext: Yes, we'll take it. Let's start out by starting in context, right? We had a pretty strong volume growth rate in Q1 but we reminded everybody that was kind of a strange comp year-over-year. We've got a very mild winter compared with a very tough winter the year before. But we said that, look, our guidance for volume has been for the year was 0.5% to 1%. And we're seeing now that our volume growth is about 1%, right? So it really is in line in total and as far as an exit speed this year with what we expected frankly, it may be due to the high end of that.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And what I would add to that also is that we did see, as I mentioned before, we did see a step that the residential volumes. And that's because of certain contracts that we did not renew because they didn't meet our return criteria. So keep that in might
componenttext: And what I would add to that also is that we did see, as I mentioned before, we did see a step that the residential volumes. And that's because of certain contracts that we did not renew because they didn't meet our return criteria. So keep that in might also. The other thing is you've got a 50 basis point sequential decline in volumes just as a the additional workday, so that how we -- obviously, that's something that we're the topline in a pretty significant matter. But as John mentioned, we still remain comfortable with our guidance of thinking about 1% for the year in volume guidance, which, as he mentioned, is in upper end of our original guidance range.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So obviously, a lot of those recoveries have been led by our C&D business, which continues to perform for us. We mentioned that churn rates our good. We mentioned, I think, protection state low. We're seeing continuing to increase slightly. We're seeing s
componenttext: So obviously, a lot of those recoveries have been led by our C&D business, which continues to perform for us. We mentioned that churn rates our good. We mentioned, I think, protection state low. We're seeing continuing to increase slightly. We're seeing service increases versus decreases continue to be incrementally favorable. So all those underlying things that point to continue to strengthen and the fundamentals are there. We're also being smart about pricing. I guess, the last thing is, and we measure that in the comments, is we have walked away from some broker business. And we have determined that, that broker model hasn't really seen for the company, and so we have intentionally shed some of that business over the last couple of quarters. So if you net that out, obviously, the numbers are quite a bit more favorable.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And can you talk a little bit, just looking at the topline as well, I mean, it looks like tuck-ins flying was a little bit lower than normal. Just Curious what you're seeing in the private market? It sounds like things have quieted down with that. And you also made some divestitures in there so...

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.  So we're a little slow out of the gate this year, but we're confident that we will intelligently spend $100 million or so in and around tuck-ins. Again, we're focused primarily in tuck-ins because of the return profile of those. And as you know, the
componenttext: Yes.  So we're a little slow out of the gate this year, but we're confident that we will intelligently spend $100 million or so in and around tuck-ins. Again, we're focused primarily in tuck-ins because of the return profile of those. And as you know, these things are kind of lumpy. But we've got a good pipeline and we've got a number of deals that we're working on now that we think we'll come through for the second half of the year and we'll be right where we said we would be.

componenttext: So first question I had was actually on the special waste environment. We do the survey every quarter and the result of the survey says everything was strong, but specially, look a little weak in [indiscernible] in our survey, so let me know  what you were seeing.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Perhaps, for us, Q2 is, again, from a comp perspective, will be tougher for us because we had a pretty large job last year on the West Coast that didn't repeat. And again, you know that, again, a better job of that sort of throw off your year-over-ye
componenttext: Yes. Perhaps, for us, Q2 is, again, from a comp perspective, will be tougher for us because we had a pretty large job last year on the West Coast that didn't repeat. And again, you know that, again, a better job of that sort of throw off your year-over-year comparison. Our first half special waste was remained about [ph] 3% above [ph] our 3-year average. So overall, we're still trending and we think in a good way. So remember, too, that a portion of our special versus manufacturing related. That manufacturing was is recurring waste stream. Those continue to be very stable and strong. And the event business, kind of similarly related to lean clearing and construction, it tends to be sporadic. And so that's what we're seeing. It's not that unusual that we want see these kind of movement. So we're -- overall construction remains pretty positive for us. So we think over the long term, we're still in pretty good shape there.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I actually had a question on recycling. As you've kind of done some restructuring in that business, I imagined we've all been focused on what happens when commodity prices are down, now it's actually trending up. Is there a formula you can
componenttext: Okay. And then I actually had a question on recycling. As you've kind of done some restructuring in that business, I imagined we've all been focused on what happens when commodity prices are down, now it's actually trending up. Is there a formula you can give us, I think, in the K, you've given a formula for each $10 per ton change those extra revenue and operating income. How did that formula changed as you've restructured the contract?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that the formula is basically the same. So for every $10 change in commodity prices for our basket of commodities, it has about a $0.03 EPS impact on the business.
componenttext: I think that the formula is basically the same. So for every $10 change in commodity prices for our basket of commodities, it has about a $0.03 EPS impact on the business.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you'll see those changing?
componenttext: And you'll see those changing?

componenttext: Well, it will change as we continue to change the contracts. So what we'll do, Corey, is when we make enough progress, will we evaluate it and we'll update probably hopefully by the time we get the guidance next year, we'll have a new view of that.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I appreciate the comments earlier that you guys have narrowed the gap between core price and yield. And maybe I'm reading into this a but much, but when you look at core price, your open market component in 2Q is 4.1%. That's down from where it was at
componenttext: So I appreciate the comments earlier that you guys have narrowed the gap between core price and yield. And maybe I'm reading into this a but much, but when you look at core price, your open market component in 2Q is 4.1%. That's down from where it was at in 1Q and it's down from, I think, it was 4.8% last year. I guess, I would've thought that this lever would've pulled a little bit harder, given the restricted component is down on CPI. Is there anything that we could point to that would maybe explain some of the moderation? Or is it just tough comps?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, we need to keep in mind that core price includes the anniversarying of recycling collection prices that we pushed real hard in Q1 of last year. So because those anniversaried, we had a little bit of a headwind in core price. But as we mentioned b
componenttext: I think, we need to keep in mind that core price includes the anniversarying of recycling collection prices that we pushed real hard in Q1 of last year. So because those anniversaried, we had a little bit of a headwind in core price. But as we mentioned before, even though we had had that headwind, we were able to keep average yields consistent at 2%.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks for the clarification there.
componenttext: Okay. Thanks for the clarification there.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Joe, our expectation is with, one, our focus on price and our internal controls around price and then our tools and Tyler mentioned, synergies, Capture and PBS. So with our tools, we keep a very close eye on that. We're rewording salespeople for selli
componenttext: And Joe, our expectation is with, one, our focus on price and our internal controls around price and then our tools and Tyler mentioned, synergies, Capture and PBS. So with our tools, we keep a very close eye on that. We're rewording salespeople for selling intelligently. So we think -- and plus the general market has been strong. Growth has been there. And our whole strategy around growth differentiation, we think our value proposition to our customers continue to improve, right? So all of that directionally says that we think we're going to continue to experience decent pricing in the open market because we earn it. And we can help offset some of these costs that we just can't normally accept through productivity. So nothing's really changed in our MO or in the overall structure of the market.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So that it's fair to say than that some of your bigger open market classes or products like commercial and landfill, are they probably seeing similar, if not better, core pricing?
componenttext: So that it's fair to say than that some of your bigger open market classes or products like commercial and landfill, are they probably seeing similar, if not better, core pricing?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, remember, on landfill specifically MSW, most of the ways that comes in is municipal under long-term contracts. We have very little open market MSW coming in our landfills anymore just because we've priced those assets according to what the realistic
componenttext: Well, remember, on landfill specifically MSW, most of the ways that comes in is municipal under long-term contracts. We have very little open market MSW coming in our landfills anymore just because we've priced those assets according to what the realistic return is for running a landfill. So -- but we do see decent pricing across the board.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, Don, just a question for you some of the customer-facing initiatives. Like you alluded to e-commerce and the release. I certainly get that this is aimed at reducing churn, and if you do that, you guys could boost the revenue and mar
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, Don, just a question for you some of the customer-facing initiatives. Like you alluded to e-commerce and the release. I certainly get that this is aimed at reducing churn, and if you do that, you guys could boost the revenue and margins. So I'm curious, have you started to see a meaningful reduction from the systems? And, I guess, more generally, when you guys think about pursuing a project like this, how do you measure the returns associated with it? And what's your expected payback period?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the -- 2 things, right? The rollout of click-to-buy or e-commerce tools, right, as I said in my commentary, we're already seeing a very high percentage of new business coming through in those markets that we rolled it out. So the return comes from t
componenttext: Well, the -- 2 things, right? The rollout of click-to-buy or e-commerce tools, right, as I said in my commentary, we're already seeing a very high percentage of new business coming through in those markets that we rolled it out. So the return comes from the fact that new business shows up with a lower cost of acquisition because basically, people are self-serving, right? They are shopping online and making the business the buying choice without having the interface with a live human being knocking on doors. And then secondly, those online purchases tend to be and have been at a higher-than-average price because the convenience of shopping online has value. And on top of that, those purchases have come where, frankly, a higher degree of contract compliance, where customers are opting in for -- to a service agreement because of the convenience of everything. So all those things have value. And now that the tools are proven, they're really user friendly and and now they're rolled out almost across all of our markets. We have to just continue to push participation in the payback will be there. And frankly, if you look around at consumerism, that's where it is today. And we've been probably a little later became as an industry, but I think as an industry, we're probably ahead of many of the other people out there, And certainly, smaller competitors who don't have the capability or it be resources to do this. And that's, of course, part of our differentiation strategy, right? We got to meet customers where they want to be, where they want to do business, when they want to do business. So overall, is just one more slice of how we're going to compete in the market, how we're going to grow revenue intelligently and how we're going to do it openly at a lower cost to acquire.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Feniger of Bank of America.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say that we are on track. We're excited when we thought we would be. Actually, as we said before, we're at the high end of our guidance right now, so we feel very comfortable with the volume growth we've seen and the velocity that we have for
componenttext: Yes, I would say that we are on track. We're excited when we thought we would be. Actually, as we said before, we're at the high end of our guidance right now, so we feel very comfortable with the volume growth we've seen and the velocity that we have for the rest of the year.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And was there anything specific in terms of any region? Or were there any slowdowns as you went through the quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And was there anything specific in terms of any region? Or were there any slowdowns as you went through the quarter?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. This is Don. I would say it's very broad-based across geographies, across most lines of business. So again, we leveled up fundamentals being strong. We talked about the fact that we're still kind of midcycle in the recovery. All those things are point
componenttext: No. This is Don. I would say it's very broad-based across geographies, across most lines of business. So again, we leveled up fundamentals being strong. We talked about the fact that we're still kind of midcycle in the recovery. All those things are pointing in the right direction, so we think it's a solid quarter. And as Chuck said, we're reiterating guidance. We're saying that we think we'll perform with the high end of that as well as commodities hold up and the volume side as well. So we're pretty pleased with how the business is performing today and economy is cooperating.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. My last question. I think restricted pricing was 1.5%. I mean, is this the bottom that we should see with how we've been seeing CPI trend? Or is this going to take another step lower in the second half of the year?
componenttext: Great. My last question. I think restricted pricing was 1.5%. I mean, is this the bottom that we should see with how we've been seeing CPI trend? Or is this going to take another step lower in the second half of the year?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is pretty much the bottom right now in terms of restricted pricing. Obviously, we've got a little bit of a CPI headwind in the second half of the year. But that's where we contemplate it in our guidance. But this should be close to the bottom ri
componenttext: Yes. This is pretty much the bottom right now in terms of restricted pricing. Obviously, we've got a little bit of a CPI headwind in the second half of the year. But that's where we contemplate it in our guidance. But this should be close to the bottom right now.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, because what you'll see probably sequentially, Mike, right, the majority of our price resets right in the second half of the year, right? So we are going to start to see picking up 2015 CPI environment and the restricted pricing in the second half of
componenttext: Yes, because what you'll see probably sequentially, Mike, right, the majority of our price resets right in the second half of the year, right? So we are going to start to see picking up 2015 CPI environment and the restricted pricing in the second half of '16 and into the first half of '17. But the one thing, obviously, is we're saying is we're going to maintain this 2% average yield, and the way we're going to do that as with a little bit better pricing in the open market. Chuck talked about some of the recycling collection pricing that we did last year Q3 that anniversaried to bring it more in line with what we charge on the solid waste site and we're going to see more of that in the second half of this year to offset the CPI headwind.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on top of that, we're also going to continue to convert people into alternative and indices and were also going to deal with the sum of the pricing that we have today in and around of recycling to make that fair for us. So that's going to continue to
componenttext: And on top of that, we're also going to continue to convert people into alternative and indices and were also going to deal with the sum of the pricing that we have today in and around of recycling to make that fair for us. So that's going to continue to happen through the cycle. And then as we've always said, a little bit of inflation is good, and if we see some of that come through, that at some point will help as well. But also, remember, right, we've been managing in a slow CPI environment for quite a long time now, and I think we've done do it pretty effectively. Think about the number of years, we're at we 1.6% [ph] average of CPI?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Brian on for Michael today. First question just on the margins. On the first have in EBITDA margins, first and second quarter is -- it was down, I think, around 40 or 50 basis points. And when you think about getting to the midpoint of the high en
componenttext: This is Brian on for Michael today. First question just on the margins. On the first have in EBITDA margins, first and second quarter is -- it was down, I think, around 40 or 50 basis points. And when you think about getting to the midpoint of the high end of your guidance, that means there's about another 120 -- 100 to 120 basis points in the second half. How should we think about that from a weighted perspective in third and fourth quarter? Is that going to be more back and we did in the fourth quarter legacy much stronger margins? Or is it going to be more even?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so right now, keep in mind that here in the second quarter, the EBITDA margins were 28.3%, right, so consistent with last year. I had a little bit of a headwind as we had mentioned in those margins because of the legal settlements that we had talked
componenttext: Yes, so right now, keep in mind that here in the second quarter, the EBITDA margins were 28.3%, right, so consistent with last year. I had a little bit of a headwind as we had mentioned in those margins because of the legal settlements that we had talked about. So if you back those out, are close to that 28.5% that we had guided to for the year. In the back half of the year, we continue to see strong EBITDA margins. Keep in mind that workday that I had talked about will also benefit the margins in the fourth quarter of the year. So right now, we feel -- we still feel very comfortable with our EBITDA margin guidance.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And we said our operating costs are improving, right? We think that continues to the second half. Again, this legal settlement doesn't repeat. All those things that continue to pull that EBITDA margin through the end of that year.
componenttext: Yes. And we said our operating costs are improving, right? We think that continues to the second half. Again, this legal settlement doesn't repeat. All those things that continue to pull that EBITDA margin through the end of that year.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Brian, you're probably going to see a heavier weighting to Q4 than to Q3, again, because of the work day the Chuck mentioned we're going to get a benefit from that. But also, we have an easier comp in the fourth quarter from the EBITDA margin performa
componenttext: And Brian, you're probably going to see a heavier weighting to Q4 than to Q3, again, because of the work day the Chuck mentioned we're going to get a benefit from that. But also, we have an easier comp in the fourth quarter from the EBITDA margin performance in the prior year. So most of it will be weighted to Q4.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wet, I guess, I will share with you what we think we have to shed because frankly, we go into this thinking that as contracts come up for renewal, that because of our relationships, because of our great service, because of all the work we're doing to impr
componenttext: Wet, I guess, I will share with you what we think we have to shed because frankly, we go into this thinking that as contracts come up for renewal, that because of our relationships, because of our great service, because of all the work we're doing to improve the customer interfaces, we think we'll be able to extend the business. But this issue of having some contract losses is just the nature of our business for us long as we been doing this. So the point to what is we had this low CPI environment, CPI environment for many years, we've kind of take it on the chin with certain customers, and we get to a point of renegotiation and then we have to express to a customer that when we entered into this agreement 5 or 10 years ago, we expected to see a 3 or 3 and a quarter percent price increase as we model and forth CPI. Instead, we've seen 1.6% or less price increase and our costs are going up at 2% or 2 and a quarter. If a customer is not willing to understand that cost model and the things that we're going to take another price reduction to go forward and it doesn't meet our return criteria, even though we may love the customer and enjoy being good citizens and a good part of the community, we've got to have a return that's appropriate. So this is just business. Right now, we're just pointing out that we expected to lose some of those contracts in Q2. And that's why we saw -- one of the reasons we saw a reduction from 2% volume growth in Q1 to 0.5%. So I don't want to blow that out of proportion. It's just part of the business. But it gets a little lumpy and when it happens, we've got to point it out. But at the same time, we're having a lot of those successes and extending business and improving our work and our value, building stronger relationships, bring in the better service and the differentiation model that we talked about. So overall, net-net of net, directionally, the economy has been good to us, the company is growing, our people are executing. The initiatives are deployed, and we're seeing that benefit in the numbers. And the quarter is performing right in line with where we thought it would be. And we were, again, saying on top of our guidance that we expected at the upper and we continue to work just decent pricing or in commodity sales. So don't blow that out of proportion.
